It came after the White House said Thursday that “all options remain on the table for the president.” Russia, a close ally of Iran, also held talks to defuse the situation, the Kremlin said. Russian President Vladimir Putin spoke Friday to both Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said, describing them as “efforts to facilitate de-escalation.” Moscow had previously kept largely quiet about the protests. Meanwhile, Iran’s exiled Crown Prince Reza Pahlavi said he was confident the Islamic Republic would fall and called for foreign intervention. Pahlavi, whose father was overthrown by Iran’s 1979 Islamic Revolution, said he still believes Trump’s promise of assistance. “I believe the president is a man of his word,” Pahlavi told reporters in Washington. “Regardless of whether action is taken or not, we as Iranians have no choice but to carry on the fight.,” he added. “I will return to Iran,” he vowed. Hours later, he urged protesters to take to the streets again from Saturday to Monday.

title: New Age | Rajuk chairman assures server restoration by Feb 1
body: Chairman of Rajdhani Unnayan Kartripakkha Reazul Islam on Monday assured real estate developers that the authority’s server would be fully operational by February 1 next. The assurance came during a meeting between the Rajuk chairman and leaders of the Real Estate and Housing Association of Bangladesh at the Rajuk headquarters, where issues related to the capital’s development planning, overall progress of the housing sector and simplification of civic services were discussed. ‘At present, Rajuk’s server is almost non-functional. However, it will be restored and made operational by February 1,’ Reazul Islam told the REHAB leaders. During the meeting, REHAB leaders urged Rajuk to expedite the approval of designs under the new Detailed Area Plan. In response, the Rajuk chairman assured them of taking steps to simplify name mutation and deed registration processes, as well as to reduce harassment faced by service seekers. ‘To ease public sufferings, digital services will be further strengthened and transparency will be ensured,’ Reazul said. REHAB senior vice-president Liakat Ali Bhuiyan, vice-president Engineer Abdul Latif and other leaders were present at the meeting. Rajuk’s server has been facing repeated disruptions for several months. Although it functions briefly at times, technical problems resurface, causing prolonged service disruptions. title: New Age | UAP terminates teachers amid protests
body: Univ Teachers’ Network denounces removal decision Authorities of the University of Asia Pacific on Sunday terminated two teachers amid protests of its former and current students alleging one’s ‘anti-hijab and ant-niqab’ remarks. The terminated teachers were assistant professor Layeqa Bashir of department of basic sciences and humanities and the department’s head assistant professor ASM Mohsin. A group of UAP students staged demonstrations on its Farmgate campus pressing several demands, including the removal of Layeqa alleging her ‘anti-hijab and ant-niqab’ remarks and removal of Mohsin for allegedly supporting her. Sunday’s termination notice of the teachers said that the decision was taken ‘in view of the prevailing situation resulting from student protests and after careful consideration of all relevant facts and circumstances’. The University Teachers’ Network on Monday issued a statement strongly protesting at and condemning the removal of the two teachers from the university. Contacted, Layeqa told New Age on Monday that a group of former students started defaming and threatening her on a social media platform over her December 10, 2025 Facebook post regarding the murder of a woman and her daughter allegedly by a masked domestic worker. ‘A group of students tagged me as “Islamophobic” and continued cyber bullying against me,’ said Layeqa, adding that the vice-canceler of the university on December 14 verbally asked her to resign. She suspected that an influential section of the university’s higher officials were behind mobilising the students. Mohsin said that he was not fully aware of the allegations against him. UAP pro-vice-chancellor Mohiuddin Ahmed Bhuiyan said that the university authorities took the termination decision in face of student protests. Asked about whether the authorities found any truth regarding students’ allegations, Mohiuddin claimed that a committee which was formed to probe the allegations against Layeqa, verbally informed the authorities that the committee found truth regarding the allegations. The University Teachers’ Network statement said that such terminations would be marked as a severe warning sign against academic freedom in the country. Earlier, Viqarunnisa Noon School and College on August 26, 2025 suspended a teacher following allegations of expelling some students for wearing hijab. Before that in March 2024, a section of Rajshahi University’s Islamic studies students demonstrated, demanding exemplary punishment of an assistant professor for forcing the female students to remove their hijab and uncover their faces. title: New Age | Trainee constable injured in accidental firing during training in Tangail
body: A trainee recruit constable was injured after being accidentally shot during firing training at Mahera Police Training Centre in Tangail on Monday. The injured was Md Masum, 19. Maruf Abdullah, assistant inspector general, health and welfare, of police headquarters, said that a bullet from a Chinese rifle suddenly struck Md Masum in the left shoulder from behind while firing practice was under way at the training centre. He was immediately rescued and taken to Tangail General Hospital where he received primary treatment. As his condition worsened, Masum was later airlifted by a RAB helicopter to the emergency department of Dhaka Medical College Hospital for advanced treatment. Doctors at DMCH said that the injured trainee constable was undergoing treatment and his condition remained critical. title: New Age | DIG Ehsanullah absent from work for over 2 months
body: No action so far No disciplinary or legal action has yet been taken against deputy inspector general of police AKM Ehsanullah, currently posted at the Bangladesh Police Academy at Sardah in Rajshahi, although he has remained absent from duty for more than two and a half months now. Mohammed Saiful Islam, superintendent of police (administration and logistics) at the academy, told New Age on Monday that they had only submitted an absence report to the police headquarters, stating that Ehsanullah was no longer attending office. ‘Taking any action is up to the home ministry,’ he said, adding that the academy had no clear information about how or when the DIG left the premises. Academy officials said that AKM Ehsanullah, a 20th Bangladesh Civil Service (police) cadre officer serving as a DIG in charge of the academy’s administration and logistics wing, had remained absent since October 29, when he stopped reporting for duty amid allegations of involvement in extrajudicial killings and other unlawful activities. They said that although Ehsanullah later sent a leave application by post, the academy authorities rejected it. But he was drawing his salaries as usual as no administrative action was taken against him so far, officials alleged. AKM Ehsanullah previously served as superintendent of police in Barishal, where he reportedly faced allegations of involvement in extrajudicial killings and other criminal acts. An investigation into the allegations against him is currently under way at the International Crimes Tribunal. According to academy sources, in the morning of October 29, a police team arrived at the academy to detain DIG Ehsanullah. However, he allegedly learned of the operation in advance and went into hiding before the team reached him. His disappearance from one of the country’s most secured police institutions has since triggered widespread discussion within the police force and raised serious questions about internal accountability. Meanwhile, responding to journalists’ questions regarding how several officers could flee from the Bangladesh Police Academy and whether any action was taken, home adviser retired Lieutenant General Jahangir Alam Chowdhury on Sunday said that the authorities were aware of the issue. ‘I don’t deny that several officers have fled from here. Measures are being taken to trace them and bring them to justice as quickly as possible,’ he said. title: New Age | Woman leaves her newborn with stranger with note
body: A woman left her 19-day-old baby with a stranger and a note at the outpatient department of the upazila health complex at Ishwardi of Pabna on Monday. The woman with the baby in her lap is named Mishti Akhter, wife of Sagar Hossain of Joynagar village of the upazila. According to relevant sources, Mishti Akhter brought her husband Sagar Hossain to the Upazila Health Complex at around 12:30 pm with fever. While waiting at the out-patient department, an unknown woman came and asked her to hold the baby for a while as she needed to use the restroom. Though Mishti waited for a long time, the woman did not reappear. Later, a note was found on the cloth wrapped around the baby. ‘You will keep the baby in your custody, the baby was born on January 1’ the note read. After getting aware of the incident, Upazila Health and Family Planning officer Dr. Ali Ehsan said that he has reported to the administration and the concerned authorities about it. title: New Age | ACC to sue ex-JP general secy Ranga for taking bribes
body: NOMINATION BUSINESS The Anti-Corruption Commission has found evidence that former state minister Moshiur Rahman Ranga, also formerly a Jatiya Party presidium member, received Tk 1.70 crore bribes for facilitating participation in the 11th Jatiya Sangsad election. The commission on Monday at a meeting decided to file a case against Ranga and former Kurigram-2 lawmaker Panir Uddin Ahmed over the alleged bribery, said its director general (prevention) Md Akhtar Hossain. According to the inquiry report, Ranga accepted the bribe from Panir Uddin Ahmed despite having no business relationship with him, in exchange for gaining him opportunities to contest the 11th parliamentary election held in 2018. The inquiry found that Panir Uddin Ahmed, proprietor of Messrs Jalil Biri Factory and a transport company named Haq Special, bank transferred Tk 20 lakh from his account to Ranga’s account on October 30, 2018. The money was transferred from an account of Haq Special at Islami Bank Bangladesh’s Kurigram branch to Ranga’s account at the bank’s Rangpur branch. In November 2018, Panir Uddin transferred Tk 1.50 crore in four instalments from Sonali Bank’s Kurigram branch to Ranga’s account at the bank’s Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban branch. Panir Uddin paid the money as bribe to former state minister for rural development and cooperatives Ranga, also former secretary general of Jatiya Party, in exchange of nomination, the inquiry report said, adding that attempts were made to conceal the transaction by adopting a roundabout way of transferring the money. The commission also decided to issue a note asking Moshiur Rahman Ranga, also former lawmaker from Rangpur-1 constituency, to submit his wealth statement to the commission over allegations of amassing illegal assets. Moshiur Rahman served as the secretary general of the Jatiya Party, appointed by the party founder HM Ershad in December 2018, but he was later removed from the position by current chairman GM Quader in 2020 and again from all party posts in 2022. title: New Age | NCP suspends Rajshahi district, city committee activities
body: The National Citizen Party on Monday suspended the activities of Rajshahi district and metropolitan city convening committees on charges of violating organisational discipline. A press issued by NCP office cell member Sadia Farzana Dina on Monday afternoon stated that the decision was taken on the instructions of party convener Md Nahid Islam and member secretary Akhtar Hossain. ‘The suspension will remain in force until further notice,’ it added. Earlier on October 30, NCP announced a new 64-member convening committee for Rajshahi city unit with previously dissolved coordination committee’s chief coordinator Mobasher Ali as the convener. A month after, on November 29, the party announced a 105-member convening committee for Rajshahi district unit with previously dissolved coordination committee’s joint-coordinator Saiful Islam as the convener. Following the announcement of the Rajshahi district committee, a faction of the newly-announced committee staged demonstrations and held press conferences demanding permanent expulsion of district convener Saiful Islam, alleging that he has links with Awami League affiliates and has been engaging in activities that threaten the party’s organisational integrity. title: New Age | 7-college students demand approval of university ord
body: Students of seven government colleges, once affiliated with Dhaka University, on Monday established ‘ordinance stages’ in front of their respective campuses demanding the approval and immediate issuance of the Dhaka Central University Ordinance 2025. They demanded that the council of advisers must approve the draft of the ordinance at its meeting scheduled for Thursday. According to the demonstrators, students of Dhaka College, Begum Badrunnesa Government Women’s College and Eden Mohila College jointly established a stage in front of the Dhaka College gate, while students of Kabi Nazrul Government College and Government Shaheed Suhrawardy College installed a stage near Bahadur Shah Park in Old Dhaka. Students of Government Bangla College and Government Titumir College established stages beside their respective campuses. Dhaka College student Abdur Rahman told New Age that they decided not to stage street demonstrations creating public suffering as the authorities had informed them about the development regarding the ordinance. ‘We will carry out campaigns from the stages to press home our demand,’ said Abdur Rahman, adding that the interim government must approve the ordinance at its Thursday advisory council meeting and immediately issue it. He also warned that any delay from the government would be met with tougher movement. The Secondary and Higher Education Division on Sunday sent the final draft of the Dhaka Central University Ordinance 2025 to the Cabinet Division after completing all due procedures, expecting its approval soon. The seven government colleges were affiliated to Dhaka University in 2017 before which they were under National University. On January 27, 2025, Dhaka University authorities decided to cancel their affiliation with the seven colleges following a longstanding movement by the tertiary level students of these colleges for a separate university. On March 16, decision was taken to name the new university Dhaka Central University. A section of teachers and students of the seven colleges, however, opposed the structure of the proposed university since the publication of the draft ordinance. Lastly in January 14–15 students of the seven colleges, pressing for the ordinance, blocked major crossings in the capital, causing terrible traffic congestion. title: New Age | Moves under way to cancel birth certificate obtained by Indian national
body: The local administration in Rajshahi has initiated formal proceedings to cancel a birth certificate fraudulently obtained by an Indian national. The Indian national allegedly used the certificate to obtain Bangladeshi citizenship. Smrity Rani Sarker, administrator of Jewpara union parishad and agriculture officer of the Department of Agricultural Extension, has submitted an application to the Rajshahi deputy director (local government), seeking cancellation of the birth certificate issued in the name of the Indian citizen. Earlier, on October 30, 2025, New Age published a report titled ‘Indian man obtains Bangladeshi citizenship using false identity’. According to the report, Saher Ali Sardar, 38, son of Sohrab Sardar of Bantai Dangapara Sani Mandir area in Murshidabad district of West Bengal, India, concealed his identity, married a woman in Dhopapara village under Puthia upazila in Rajshahi, and managed to obtain Bangladeshi documents. He later obtained a Bangladeshi birth registration in March 2020 and a national identity card in July 2022 under the name Md Akash Pramanik. The birth certificate — number 19988118254105789 — was recorded at Jewpura union parishad showing Md Akash Pramanik as the son of Md Ajit Ali and Asma Begum, residents of Dhopapara village under Puthia upazila in Rajshahi. According to his Indian unique identification card (ID number 339991663915), Saher Ali was born on January 1, 1988. However, In Bangladeshi documents, Akash Pramanik’s birth certificate (No 1998811820415762) lists his date of birth as January 15, 1990, and his address as Dhopapara village at Puthia upazila in Rajshahi. Puthia upazila nirbahi officer Liaquat Salman told New Age that following media reports, the district administration formed a probe committee to investigate the allegations, and the committee had recently submitted its report. ‘The committee found the allegations to be true. The Indian citizen falsely identified himself as a member of a local Bangladeshi family and used the forged birth certificate to obtain a Bangladeshi national identity card,’ the UNO said. He added that the probe report, along with an application, had been forwarded to the district administration to cancel the birth certificate that was used to secure the national identity card. Asked about possible legal action against the Indian national, Liaquat Salman said that further steps would be taken as per directives from higher authorities. Rajshahi deputy director (local government) Md Zakiul Islam could not be reached for comment despite repeated attempts over phone. title: New Age | SECTARIAN VIOLENCE: One in every 11 reported cases communal in nature: govt
body: The government on Monday claimed that only one in every 11 reported incidents of communal violence involving members of minority communities in 2025 was identified as communal in nature. A press release issued by the chief adviser’s press wing said that there were 645 reported incidents of communal violence in 2025, of which 71 were identified as having communal elements. The release, referring to a yearlong review of official police records from January to December 2025, said that 574 of the incidents were assessed as non-communal in nature. Of the 71 incidents identified as having communal elements, one involved murder, 38 involved vandalism of temples, one involved theft at a temple, eight involved arson attacks on temples, and 23 others included threats to break idols, Facebook posts and damage to worship pavilions, the release said. It said that 50 cases were filed in these connections and 50 were arrested, and the police also took 21 other measures. Of the 574 incidents having no communal elements, 51 were neighborhood disputes, 23 land-related disputes, 106 thefts, 26 prior enmity, 172 unnatural deaths, 58 rapes, and 138 others including abduction, intimidation and extortion, the release pointed out. The release said that 154 cases were filed in these connections and 498 people were arrested and the police took other measures in 30 cases. The release said that Bangladesh remained committed to confronting crime with transparency, accuracy, and resolve. The statement cannot be accepted as it is confusing and not true, said Bangladesh Hindu Buddhist Christian Unity Council general secretary Monindra Kumar Nath. ‘People will not believe such a statement,’ he said. Referring to reports published in newspapers, he said that 114 incidents of temple vandalism were reported and questioned how the government could describe those incidents as ‘having no communal elements’. ‘We have found that 32 women were raped as part of communal violence, but the government’s release shows that 58 rape incidents took place that were not communal,’ he said, questioning the credibility of the report. ‘While every incident is a matter of concern, the data presents a clear and evidence-based picture: the overwhelming majority of cases were criminal in nature rather than communal, underscoring both the complexity of law-and-order challenges and the importance of grounding public discussion in facts rather than fear or misinformation,’ said the CA’s press wing release. ‘In contrast, the majority of incidents affecting minority individuals or properties arose from criminal activity unrelated to religion, including neighborhood disputes, land conflicts, political rivalries, theft, sexual violence, and cases linked to prior personal enmity,’ the release said. title: New Age | Trump to charge $1b for ‘peace board’ membership
body: US president Donald Trump’s government has asked countries to pay $1 billion for a permanent spot on his ‘Board of Peace’ aimed at resolving conflicts, according to US media reports. The White House has asked various world leaders to sit on the board, chaired by Trump himself, including Russian President Vladimir Putin, Hungarian premier Viktor Orban and Canada’s Mark Carney. Member countries — represented on the board by their head of state — would be allowed to join for three years, or longer if they contributed more than $1 billion within the first year, according to Bloomberg, which first reported the sum. ‘Each Member State shall serve a term of no more than three years from this Charter’s entry into force, subject to renewal by the Chairman,’ stated the board’s draft charter obtained by Bloomberg and other media. ‘The three-year membership term shall not apply to Member States that contribute more than USD $1,00,00,00,000 in cash funds to the Board of Peace within the first year of the Charter’s entry into force.’ The board was originally conceived to oversee the rebuilding of Gaza, but its charter, widely cited by US media, does not appear to limit its role to the Palestinian territory. The White House said there would be a main board, a Palestinian committee of technocrats meant to govern the war-wracked territory, and a second ‘executive board’ that appears designed to have a more advisory role. ‘The Board of Peace is an international organisation that seeks to promote stability, restore dependable and lawful governance, and secure enduring peace in areas affected or threatened by conflict,’ the charter says. The document was sent to dozens of world leaders who were invited to join the board, the Times of Israel reported. It appears to take a swipe at international institutions such as the United Nations, saying that the board should have ‘the courage to depart from approaches and institutions that have too often failed.’ Trump has regularly criticised the United Nations and announced this month that his country will withdraw from 66 global organisations and treaties — roughly half affiliated with the UN. Membership of the board would be ‘limited to States invited to participate by the Chairman’, according to the full draft charter published by the Times of Israel. Trump would have the power to remove member states from the board, subject to a veto by two-third of members, and choose his replacement should he leave his role as chairman. The ‘Board of Peace’ began to take shape on Saturday as the leaders of Egypt, Turkey, Argentina and Canada were asked to join. Trump also named his secretary of state Marco Rubio, former British prime minister Tony Blair, and senior negotiators Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff as members. Israel has objected to the line-up of a ‘Gaza executive board’ to operate under the body, which includes Turkish foreign minister Hakan Fidan and Qatari diplomat Ali Al-Thawadi. title: New Age | 2 suspected cattle lifters lynched in Manikganj
body: Two suspected cattle lifters were killed in a lynch-mob attack at Imannagar village under Singair in Manikganj early Monday. title: New Age | Iran police chief issues surrender ultimatum over ‘riots’
body: Iran’s national police chief said on Monday that people who were ‘deceived’ into joining demonstrations the authorities have deemed ‘riots’ would receive lighter punishment if they turned themselves in within three days. ‘Young people who became unwittingly involved in the riots are considered to be deceived individuals, not enemy soldiers’, and ‘will be treated with leniency by the Islamic republic system’, Ahmad-Reza Radan told state television, adding they had ‘a maximum of three days’ to surrender. Demonstrations sparked in late December by anger over economic hardship exploded into protests widely seen as the biggest challenge to the Iranian leadership in years. The protests subsided after a violent crackdown rights groups said left thousands dead. Iranian officials have said the demonstrations were peaceful before turning into ‘riots’ fuelled by Iran’s arch-foes the United States and Israel and aimed at destabilising the Islamic republic. Security officials cited by the Tasnim news agency said late last week around 3,000 people have been arrested in connection to the demonstrations, as rights groups say the number is up to 20,000. Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said on Saturday authorities ‘must break the back of the seditionists’ and said domestic and foreign ‘criminals’ would not be spared punishment. Meanwhile, thousands in the United States staged large demonstrations Sunday denouncing the Iranian government’s deadly crackdown on anti-government protesters in the Islamic Republic. Several thousand people marched in Los Angeles, home to the world’s largest Iranian diaspora, while several hundred others gathered in New York, AFP journalists in both cities reported. US protesters could be seen carrying signs condemning a ‘New Holocaust,’ a ‘genocide in the making,’ and the ‘terror’ of the Iranian government. ‘My heart is heavy and my soul is crushed, I’m at loss for words to describe how angry I am,’ said Perry Faraz at the demonstration in Los Angeles, the second-largest city in the US. The 62-year-old payroll manager, who fled Iran in 2006, learned this week that one of her young cousins had been killed during the overseas rallies held in her native country. ‘He wasn’t even 10 years old, that’s horrible,’ she said. Demonstrations sparked by anger over economic hardship exploded into protests late December in what has been widely seen as the biggest challenge to the Iranian leadership in recent years. The rallies subsided after a government crackdown in Iran that rights groups have called a ‘massacre’ carried out by security forces under the cover of a communications blackout that started on January 8. Norway-based Iran Human Rights says it has verified the deaths of 3,428 protesters killed by security forces, confirming cases through sources within the Islamic Republic’s health and medical system, witnesses and independent sources. The NGO warned that the true toll is likely to be far higher. Media cannot independently confirm the figure and Iranian officials have not given an exact death toll. ‘This mass murdering of the population is terribly upsetting,’ Ali Parvaneh, a 65-year-old lawyer protesting in LA said. title: New Age | Surging wealth of billionaires a political threat: Oxfam
body: The collective wealth of the planet’s billionaires soared to a record level in 2025, charity Oxfam reported Monday, warning of ‘highly dangerous’ political consequences as the global elite gathers for the World Economic Forum. US president Donald Trump’s policies in particular spurred the fortunes of the ultra-rich, which jumped 16.2 per cent in the first year of his second term to $18.3 trillion, the NGO said in a report released each year ahead of the Davos forum. ‘Actions of the Trump presidency including the championing of deregulation and undermining agreements to increase corporate taxation have benefited the richest around the world,’ Oxfam said. The world now has more than 3,000 billionaires for the first time, it added, with the top 12 — led by Tesla and SpaceX chief Elon Musk — having ‘more wealth than the poorest half of humanity, or more than four billion people’. Increasingly this money is buying political power, Oxfam said, pointing in particular to tycoons’ buying newspapers and other media, such as Musk’s takeover of X or the purchase of The Washington Post by Amazon’s Jeff Bezos. ‘The widening gap between the rich and the rest is at the same time creating a political deficit that is highly dangerous and unsustainable,’ Oxfam’s executive director Amitabh Behar said. Trump will arrive with one of the biggest US delegations ever for the Davos conference, where he is expected to dominate an agenda officially billed as ‘A Spirit of Dialogue’. Trump’s participation galvanised around 300 protesters who arrived in Davos on Sunday, many wearing masks of Musk or US vice president JD Vance and holding fistfuls of euros. Nathalie Ruoss of the Swiss Young Socialists said the most powerful people in the world make decisions at Davos that impact everyone. ‘And they do it with no democratic legitimacy,’ she said, calling it ‘unacceptable’ that the WEF welcomed ‘fascists like Donald Trump’. For Oxfam, Washington’s decision to exempt US multinationals from an internationally agreed minimum tax rate of 15 per cent was a stark example of ignoring growing inequality. ‘In country after country, the super-rich have not only accumulated more wealth than could ever be spent, but have also used this wealth to secure the political power to shape the rules that define our economies and govern nations,’ it said. ‘Such power gives billionaires a grasp over all our futures, undermining political freedom and eroding the rights of the many.’ Editor: Nurul Kabir, Published by the Chairman, Editorial Board ASM Shahidullah Khan on behalf of Media New Age Ltd. +8802-9632245-48 [email protected] For Advertisement, Cell: +8801849 263831 Email: [email protected]

title: New Age | Afghan officials meets commerce secy in Dhaka
body: A visiting delegation from the commerce and industry ministry of Afghanistan on Monday called on Bangladesh’s commerce secretary Mahbubur Rahman at his secretariat office in the capital Dhaka in a move to boost bilateral trade between the two countries. The Taliban government’s business delegation led by industry and commerce deputy minister Ahmadullah Zahid expressed interest in expanding bilateral trade and exploring specific areas of cooperation, officials said. ‘The Afghan government is willing to enhance bilateral trade with us. We have advised them to raise any trade-related issues through the diplomatic channel and engage with the local businesses to explore specific business opportunities,’ commerce secretary Mahbubur Rahman told New Age. The meeting was held on the sidelines of Afghanistan’s participation in the ongoing Dhaka International Trade Fair at Purbachal, on the outskirts of the capital, according to officials. Mahbubur said that the delegation came to Bangladesh to attend the DITF and expressed its willingness for the meeting. Meanwhile, a non-verified X account named ‘Ministry of Industry and Commerce Afghanistan’ shared a photo of the meeting. The X handle also said that the Deputy Minister of Industry and Commerce of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan met with his Bangladeshi counterpart. At the meeting, the Bangladeshi commerce secretary welcomed the Afghan delegation and expressed satisfaction with the expansion of relations between the two countries, said the statement shared on the social media. It also stated that the two sides discussed increasing trade volume through preferential agreements, exporting medicines and textiles to Afghanistan, along with introducing trade attachés in both countries. According to a report published on BBC Dari on Sunday, the Taliban government said that a delegation from the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, along with 50 businessmen left for Bangladesh. In September 2025, a seven-member delegation of Bangladeshi religious scholars, led by Mamunul Haque, travelled to Afghanistan at the ‘invitation of the Taliban government,’ according to the BBC report. In December, Afghanistan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ director general Noor Ahmad Noor met senior figures, including Mamunul Haque, leader of the Bangladesh Khelafat Majlis, and reportedly visited several madrassahs during his visit to Bangladesh. The Taliban came back to power in Afghanistan as the then Afghan government collapsed amid the withdrawal of forces by the United States and the NATO from the South Asian country in August 2021. Bangladesh like many other countries is yet to recognise the Taliban government although it maintains diplomatic ties. title: New Age | Train crash kills 39 in Spain
body: The Spanish government vowed Monday to conduct a full investigation into the causes of a high-speed train collision that killed at least 39 people, with officials warning the death toll could rise as rescuers worked among the wreckage. The crash late on Sunday is Spain’s deadliest train accident since 2013, when 80 people died after a train veered off a curved section of track outside the northwestern city of Santiago de Compostela. The latest happened when a train operated by rail company Iryo travelling from Malaga to Madrid derailed near Adamuz in Andalucia. It crossed onto the other track, where it crashed into an oncoming train, which also derailed. ‘This is a day of sorrow for all of Spain, for our entire country,’ prime minister Pedro Sanchez told reporters during a visit to Adamuz as he declared three days of mourning. ‘We will uncover the answer, and once the cause of this tragedy is determined, we will present it with absolute transparency.’ The interior ministry said 39 people died. Over 120 people were injured, with 43 still in hospital, regional emergency services said. Of those, 12 were in intensive care. Heavy machinery was being deployed to lift the most severely damaged train carriages, the head of the regional government of Andalucia, Juan Manuel Moreno, told reporters. ‘Unfortunately, it is quite possible that additional victims will be found beneath the twisted wreckage. The goal is to identify the victims as quickly as possible,’ he added. Unlike the 2013 accident, the derailment occurred on a straight section of track, and the trains were travelling within the speed limit, officials said. Transport minister Oscar Puente said the first train to derail was ‘practically new’ and the section of the track where the disaster happened had been recently renovated, making the accident ‘extremely strange’. Train operator Iryo said the locomotive was built in 2022 and last inspected just three days before the accident. It said it ‘veered onto the adjacent track for still unknown reasons’. The company said around 300 people were on board its service from the Andalusian city of Malaga to the capital, Madrid. Renfe, the operator of the second train travelling to the southern city of Huelva, said it was carrying 184 passengers. Human error has ‘been practically ruled out’, Renfe president Alvaro Fernandez Heredia told Spanish public radio RNE. ‘It must be related to Iryo’s rolling stock or an infrastructure issue,’ he added. The stretch of track where the accident happened had a speed limit of 250 kilometres per hour, Heredia said. One train was travelling at 205 kilometres per hour, and the other 210 kilometres per hour, he added. Spain has Europe’s largest high-speed rail network, with more than 3,000 kilometres of dedicated tracks connecting major cities including Madrid, Barcelona, Seville, Valencia and Malaga. Survivor Lucas Meriako, who was travelling on the first train that derailed, told La Sexta television that it looked ‘like a horror movie’. ‘We felt a very strong hit from behind and the feeling that the whole train was about to collapse, break there were many injured due to the glass,’ he said. Residents of Adamuz, which is filled with white buildings and streets lined with orange trees, were grappling with the aftermath of the disaster. ‘This is a catastrophe for us,’ Jose Perez Rojas, an 80-year-old pensioner, said, calling it ‘really shocking’. Manuel Munoz, 60, an olive oil factory worker, said locals rushed to the centre of the town as word of the accident spread. ‘We started bringing water, blankets, everything we could. We helped unload vans bringing more supplies,’ he said. French president Emmanuel Macron and European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen were among world leaders offering condolences. title: New Age | Experts for strong city govts to improve civic services
body: Urban planners and experts at a dialogue on Monday said that significant improvement in civic services in Dhaka and other cities was possible if an effective and functional local government system could be put in place. The Urban Development Journalists Forum Bangladesh organised the event in cooperation with the Gulshan Society in the capital. Speakers said that city residents were suffering amid a serious lack of essential facilities, including proper waste management, housing, utilities, transport and open spaces. They noted that poor coordination among the service-providing agencies multiplied public suffering, as local governments remained weak and largely ineffective. Bangladesh Institute of Planners general secretary Musleh Uddin Hasan said that in the absence of effective governance, Dhaka and other cities in the country were expanding in a totally unplanned way, causing serious environmental damage. ‘Instead of comfortable urban living, cities have turned into jungles of buildings and cars,’ he said. Speakers also said that children were forced to study under lamps even during daylight hours as houses were dark inside as robust urban planning remained absent. A severe lack of playgrounds and public spaces also are depriving children from opportunities for recreation and social interaction. Vice-chancellor of Manarat International University and environmentalist Abdur Rab expressed concern particularly about Dhaka city becoming increasingly polluted. Gulshan Society president Omar Sadat presented the keynote paper and said that air pollution was causing widespread illnesses, reducing residents’ life expectancy. Speakers urged political parties to clearly reflect their commitments to strengthening local government systems in their election manifestos. Bangladesh Nationalist Party leader Abdus Salam said that governmental agencies in Dhaka lacked coordination, which worsened public suffering. ‘Without a strong city government, service-providing agencies cannot work in a coordinated manner,’ he said. He also suggested that Dhaka mayors should come directly under the prime minister instead of the local government ministry. Mayor of Dhaka North City Corporation Mohammad Azaz said that mayors could do little with the limited resources currently available to them. National Citizen Party senior joint convener Ariful Islam Adib said that his party was committed to establishing a city government system. Among others, Ziaur Rahman Foundation executive director Farhad Halim Doner, architect Rafiq Azam, engineer and planner Md Nurullah, Gulshan Society vice-president Syed Almas Kabir and UDJFB president Matin Abdullah also spoke at the event. title: New Age | One more dies of dengue, 29 hospitalised in 24 hours
body: The Directorate General of Health Services on Monday reported that one more patient died of dengue in the past 24 hours, raising the death toll from the mosquito-borne disease to two so far this year. Of the newly admitted patients, seven were hospitalised in Barishal division (outside city corporation areas), five in Dhaka North City Corporation, five in Dhaka South City Corporation, eight in Chattogram division (outside city corporation areas) and four in Khulna division (outside city corporation areas). title: New Age | 6 young artists selected at 30th Berger contest
body: The third and final jury session for the 30th Berger Young Painters’ Art Competition concluded on January 14, where this year’s top 6 artists were selected by a distinguished jury board in presence of Berger Paints’ senior management. title: New Age | Referendum to prevent rise of fascism in future: Farida
body: Fisheries and livestock adviser Farida Akhter at a rally in Pirojpur on Monday said that the referendum was being held so that no fascism or autocracy could ever rise again in the country in future. ‘If the people believe that by voting “Yes” they can take the country one step forward toward a new and democratic system of governance, they will give their verdict accordingly,’ she said. She made the remarks while addressing as chief guest at a rally at Pirojpur Government Boys’ High School, promoting the referendum, said a press release. Organised by the Pirojpur district administration, deputy commissioner of Pirozpur Abu Sayeed presided over the programme. Superintendent of police Mohammad Manjur Ahmed Siddique, deputy director of the district information office Parikshit Choudhury and district election officer Md Abdul Mannan, among others, were present at the event. The upcoming election is not only about electing representatives, arrangements have also been made to take the people’s opinions through a referendum on important issues related to state governance, said Farida. Mentioning that four fundamental issues have been presented to the people as a single package, through which they will express their views by agreeing or disagreeing, Farida said that the candidates, who would win the election, go to the parliament, take responsibility for running the state and form the government. ‘They, however, will have no opportunity to work against the July Charter. The July Charter will be the foundation of the future state system,’ she noted. The adviser said that various reform initiatives, including an independent police commission, had already been adopted through ordinances and work on these issues was going on. Farida Akhter, in response to a question about whether the government can speak on the matters after the election schedule is announced, said, ‘The government is not campaigning for or against any candidate or political party. Rather, this is part of the government’s responsibility in accordance with cabinet decisions.’ She said that the interim government was working not only to organise elections, but also to seek public opinion on what the future state system should be like. In regard of the constitutional reform, she said that provisions of the constitution that were anti-people and used to concentrate power had shown the need for change. She, however, emphasised that there was no basis for concern that constitutional reform would undermine fundamental rights or religious freedom. title: New Age | Ambulance catches fire on Mawa expressway
body: An ambulance carrying a patient caught fire on the Dhaka–Mawa Expressway on Monday due to a mechanical fault that overheated the engine. Witnesses said that the incident occurred around 2:00pm on the Dhaleshwari Bridge in the Kuchiamora area of Sirajdikhan upazila. The patient and six other passengers managed to get out of the vehicle unhurt in time. According to the Fire Service and Civil Defence, the ambulance was travelling from Dhaka Medical College Hospital to Jhenaidah, carrying a patient along with the relatives. Fire service officials said that as the ambulance reached the Dhaleshwari Bridge, a mechanical problem caused the engine to become overheated, triggering a fire and thick smoke. The driver immediately stopped the vehicle, allowing the patient and all passengers to get off quickly before the fire engulfed the ambulance, witnesses said. Sirajdikhan Fire Service inspector Arif Anwar said that firefighters rushed to the spot and brought the blaze under control. ‘Although the ambulance was damaged in the fire, all seven passengers are safe and unharmed,’ he added. title: New Age | JCD protest at removal of banner hailing Tarique
body: Leaders and activists of Bangladesh Jatiyatabadi Chhatra Dal, student wing of Bangladesh Nationalist Party, on Monday protested against the removal of a banner, greeting BNP chairman Tarique Rahman, by student leader Salahuddin Ammar. They formed a human chain on the Paris Road, adjacent to the RU senate building, and submitted a memorandum to vice-chancellor Professor Saleh Hasan Naqib, demanding action against Ammar, general secretary of Rajshahi University Central Students’ Union. On Sunday, Ammar removed the banner installed on Paris Road by professor Mohammad Nesar Uddin, the RU Arabic department professor and Rajshahi district council president, congratulating Tarique Rahman on becoming the BNP chairman. Ammar claimed that Section 55 (2) of the Rajshahi University Act, 1973, prohibits party politics, political campaigns on campus, and the use of teachers’ associations for partisan political activities. Addressing the human chain, the JCD leaders termed Ammar a mental patient who had allegedly been destroying teacher-student relations and the overall academic environment on the campus. JCD RU unit president Sultan Ahmed Rahi said that the university administration was responsible for the removal of the banner and warned of consequences if action was not taken against Ammar within 24 hours. ‘For the sake of maintaining a healthy academic environment, we have so far exercised restraint. We demand that the university administration arrange proper mental treatment for this mentally unstable person within 24 hours,’ he said. Rahi claimed that failure to do so would be taken as evidence that the administration had directly instructed the tearing down of the banner hung to greet Tarique Rahman. Expressing solidarity with the programme, Rajshahi Zia Parishad president and Arabic department professor Mphammad Nesar Uddin said that tearing banners would not weaken nationalist politics. ‘The way Ammar tore the banner has deeply hurt us. We are shocked and heartbroken,’ Nesar Uddin said, demanding strict punishment. title: New Age | Vagabond-turned-serial killer killed six people at Savar in 6 months: police
body: The police have claimed that a vagabond identified as Mashiur Rahman Khan Sumon, also known as ‘Psycho Samrat’, was involved in six murders at Savar in Dhaka over the past 6-7 months. District additional superintendent of police, crime, Arafatul Islam revealed this information while speaking at a press briefing held at Savar model police station on Monday. On Sunday, detectives arrested Mashiur Rahman Khan Sumon, whose killing spree qualifies him as a highly prolific serial killer, at Savar after analysing the CCTV footage of the area. Later, he was produced before the court on Monday with 10-day remand prayer. Samrat, a resident of Bank Colony area under Savar municipality, used to roam around different areas of Savar. After August 5, 2024, he had allegedly been moving around for a long time wearing a police uniform and carrying a stick, often speaking incoherently, said the police. Samrat was a vagabond and he reportedly committed his first murder about seven months ago by killing an elderly woman named Asma near the Model Mosque at Savar municipality, said ASP Arafatul. On August 29, Samrat killed a young man after tying his hands and legs at the Savar Municipal Community Centre. On October 11, the police recovered the body of an unidentified woman, aged around 30, from inside the same community centre. On December 19, the police recovered the burnt body of a man from a toilet on the second floor of an abandoned municipal community centre in the Thana Road area of Savar. The police said that the accused initially confessed to his involvement in the killings. ‘We are investigating whether anyone else was involved in the crimes,’ said ASP Arafatul Islam. The identities of five of the victims, however, could not be confirmed yet. On Sunday, the police recovered two charred bodies from an abandoned community centre in Savar municipality area. title: New Age | Court appoints receiver to manage properties of ex-air chief, wife
body: A Dhaka court on Monday ordered to appoint a receiver to manage immovable properties of former air chief marshal Shaikh Abdul Hannan and his wife Tahmida Begum. The properties placed under receivership include two flats in the Badda area of Dhaka registered in the name of Sheikh Abdul Hannan; a structure built on 7.84 decimals of land at Rupganj in Narayanganj and a structure built on 320 square feet of land at Pallabi in Dhaka. Another flat at Pallabi is registered in the name of Tahmida Begum. Dhaka metropolitan senior special judge Md Sabbir Faiz passed the order, allowing a plea filed by the Anti-Corruption Commission. According to the application, case has been filed against Sheikh Abdul Hannan and his wife Tahmida Begum on allegations of abuse of power, causing loss to the state exchequer, accepting bribes, trading in appointments and embezzling funds through various irregularities and corrupt practices, including laundering money abroad, as well as acquiring assets disproportionate to known sources of income in their own names and in the names of other family members with vested interests. During the investigation, it was found that two accused acquired such disproportionate assets through abuse of power, corruption and other illegal means. Information obtained from various sources during the probe indicated that they and their family members were attempting to transfer, relocate or dispose of the immovable properties. The application further stated that appointing a receiver was essential to ensure proper control, management, supervision and maintenance of the land, structures, flats and other attached assets specified in the order. title: New Age | Woman to die for killing husband in Netrakona
body: A Netrakona court on Monday sentenced a woman to death for killing her husband over a marital dispute at Kalmakanda upazila in the district in 2021. District and sessions judge Morium-Mun-Munjury pronounced the verdict in presence of the convict in a crowded courtroom. The court also fined convicted woman Rubina Akhter, 28, Tk 50,000, a court official said. According to prosecution, Rubina Akhter killed her husband, Rukku Mia, by striking him on the head with an axe while he was asleep on the night of May 14, 2021, the day of Eid-ul-Fitr. The police later recovered Rukku Mia’s blood-stained body from the scene. Later, the victim’s younger brother Asad Mia filed a case with Kalmakanda police station, naming Rubina Akhter as the sole accused. After investigation, the police submitted a charge sheet, and the court delivered the verdict after examining the testimonies of 11 witnesses. title: New Age | CHANKHARPOOL KILLINGS: ICT set to deliver verdict today
body: The International Crimes Tribunal-1 is scheduled to deliver the verdict today in the crimes against humanity case over the killing of six protesters at Chankharpool in the capital during the July 2024 mass uprising. The three-judge tribunal, chaired by Justice Golam Mortuza Mozumder, set the date on December 24, 2025, after concluding the hearing of the first July case of the ICT-1. This will be the second verdict of the reconstituted ICT-1 in the first July case, which accuses former DMP commissioner Habibur Rahman, four senior police officers, and three constables. The seven other accused include former DMP joint commissioner Sudip Kumar Chakraborty, former Ramna assistant deputy commissioner Shah Alam Md Akhterul Islam, former Ramna assistant commissioner Mohammad Imrul, Shahbagh police station inspector (operations) Ashrad Hossain, and suspended constables Sujan Hossain, Imaz Hossain Imon, and Nasirul Islam. Of them, Ashrad and suspended constables Sujan Hossain, Imaz Hossain Imon, and Nasirul Islam are in jail. The remaining four are still in hiding and were tried in absentia. Although deposed prime minister Sheikh Hasina, former home minister Asaduzzaman Khan and detained former inspector general of police Chowdhury Abdullah Al Mamun were named as conspirators in the Chankharpool killings, they were not included in this case because they are already accused in a separate case over superior command responsibility for the July incidents. On November 17, Hasina and Asaduzzaman were tried in absentia and sentenced to death, while Mamun, who became a state witness, was jailed for five years. According to the charge sheet, senior police officials allegedly ordered, abetted, and facilitated the shootings, while constables carried out the firing that left six protesters dead on August 5, 2024 when Sheikh Hasina fled the country amid student-led mass uprising. The victims of the August 5, 2024 shooting are Shahriar Khan Anas, a class X student who left behind a heartbreaking letter to his mother, Sheikh Mahadi Hasan Zunayed who is also known as Mostakin, Mohammad Yakub, Md Rakib Hawlader, Mohammad Ismail Haque, and Manik Mia, also known as Saharik Chowdhury. title: New Age | Retrospective of Amanul Huq under way at National Museum
body: As a part of the ongoing Chobi Mela, ‘The Romantic Documentarian’ by Amanul Huq, a retrospective exhibition of pioneer of creative photography in Bangladesh, is under way at the Nalinikanta Bhattashali Gallery at the National Museum. The exhibition displayed more than fifty photographs from the collection of Drik Picture Library Archive, which was jointly researched by Ahmed Arup Kamal and Shahadat Parvez. The retrospective briefly displayed his works in three series, ‘Political Movement and 1971’, ‘Satyajit Ray’ and ‘The Bengal Delta and Its River’. In ‘Political Movement and 1971’, he archived the political events, the language movement of 1952, the mass uprising of 1969, and the long path to liberation in 1971, while “The Bengal Delta and Its River” showed rivers and life of the people of Bengal, and in ‘Satyajit Ray’, he depicted the renowned filmmaker on the film set. The exhibition will end on January 31. title: New Age | Authors responsible for narrating history: discussion
body: Writers, theatre activists and critics on Monday said that although the creative process needs liberty, authors should be responsible for narrating history. They also said that in historical or biography fiction, authors should base their work on the context and use references. They made the remarks at a seminar titled ‘Etihaser Bartaman, Bartamaner Etihas: Prekhit Shaista Kha’r Pori’ at the seminar hall of Bangladesh Shilpakala Academy. Organised by Ayan Prokashan, theatre critic Abu Sayed Tulu presented the keynote paper at the seminar which was chaired by poet and thinker Foyez Alam. Jahangirnagar University professor Masood Imran Mannu, theatre activist Irene Parveen Lopa, senior lecturer of Theatre and Media Studies at Tejgaon College and writer Ismail Hossain, among others, spoke at the event. Abu Sayed Tulu said that the novel narrated the tragic death of Pori Bibi, daughter of Mughal Subahdar of Bengal, Shaista Kha, and also detailed the historical architecture of Lalbagh Fort in the old city of Dhaka while the author portrayed the history of Bengal and Shaista Kha’s tenure as a ruler. Masood Imran Mannu said that in historical fiction, the time frame of the characters and places of the history need to be appropriate for readers and for documentation. ‘The novel titled Shaista Kha’r Pori slips from the history and also historical context,’ said Mannu, adding that many fiction writers including Humayun Ahmed and Sunil Gangopadhyay used footnotes for historical references. Irene Parveen Lopa said that the novel was based on a historical character but created many scenography based on creative fantasy. The novel titled Shaista Kha’r Pori, written by Ismail Hossain, was published in 2016 and Meghdoot Natya Sampraday brought it to the stage, while the stage play was written by Abu Sayed Tulu and directed by Subhasish Datta Tanmoy. title: New Age | Cleanliness drive begins in Nabaganga River
body: A three-day cleanliness drive began in the Nabaganga River in Jhenaidah on Monday with the aim of preserving environmental balance and reviving the river. Deputy commissioner Abdullah Al Masud inaugurated the drive at 9:30am at Castle Bridge of the district town. Among others, deputy director of the Local Government Department Rathindranath Roy, executive engineer of Jhenaidah Water Development Board Ranjan Kumar Das, assistant director of the district environment department Muntasir Rahman, president of Jhenaidah Press Club Asif Iqbal Makhon and general secretary Aminul Islam Liton, among others, were present at the event. The Nabaganga River cleaning campaign will continue until Wednesday. Speaking on the occasion, the deputy commissioner said, ‘If the river survives, nature and the environment will remain balanced. We have initially started this campaign to make the Nabaganga River pollution-free.’ He added that similar cleanliness drives would be carried out in other rivers of the district in phases. ‘Efforts are also under way to remove illegal structures built along both banks of the river.’ Editor: Nurul Kabir, Published by the Chairman, Editorial Board ASM Shahidullah Khan on behalf of Media New Age Ltd. +8802-9632245-48 [email protected] For Advertisement, Cell: +8801849 263831 Email: [email protected]

title: New Age | Khaleda’s contribution to higher edn remembered
body: Leaders of the Association of Private Universities of Bangladesh have expressed deep condolence at the death of Khaleda Zia, three-time prime minister of Bangladesh and recalled her contribution to the higher education sector of Bangladesh. An eight-member delegation of APUB, led by its president Md Sabur Khan and secretary general Ishtiaque Abedin, paid a courtesy call on Bangladesh Nationalist Party chairman Tarique Rahman at his Gulshan office on Sunday. Under the leadership of Khaleda Zia, a landmark policy decision was adopted in the National Parliament in 1992 to establish private universities for the first time in the country — ushering in a transformative era in Bangladesh’s higher education system, they recalled. The APUB leaders said that more than 400,000 students today are pursuing higher education under internationally recognised curricula. This has played a significant role in human resource development, employment generation, and strengthening global connectivity. At the meeting, Tarique Rahman highlighted content creation, freelancing, and online trading facilities as important sources of foreign currency earnings for educated youth, professionals, and entrepreneurs. He also mentioned plans to establish modern hi-tech cities to support and facilitate these activities. BNP Standing Committee Member Salahuddin Ahmed; APUB vice-chairman KBM Moin Uddin Chishti; chairman of the Board of Trustees of North South University Aziz Al Kaiser; chairperson of the Board of Trustees of BRAC University Tamara Hasan Abed; member of the Board of Trustees of North South University MA Kashem; and member of the Board of Trustees of Independent University, Bangladesh Javed Hossain were present at the meeting. title: New Age | China for Teesta Master Plan work soon: Rizwana
body: Information and broadcasting and environment, forests and climate change and water resources adviser Syeda Rizwana Hasan in Rangpur on Monday said that China wanted to start Teesta Master Plan’s work as soon as possible. The adviser made the remarks while talking to journalists after visiting the erosion-prone area of the River Teesta along with Chinese ambassador to Bangladesh Yao Wen at Tepamadhupur Taluk Shahbazpur under Kaunia in the district, said a press release. Rizwana Hasan said, ‘Both Bangladesh and Chinese governments are committed to implementing the Teesta Master Plan. Since the verification process of the project is not completed, it is not possible to start its work right now.’ She said that political parties of the country were also promising to implement the Teesta Master Plan in their manifestos for the upcoming 13th Jatiya Sangsad elections. Noting that it is not that the work will start by January 26 in a hurry, she said, ‘We are giving some time so that the work is done better. But there is no need to spread disappointment about this.’ She mentioned that after receiving the project, they sent it to China with public hearings and opinions of experts at the national level. ‘Now Chinese experts are scrutinising and sorting it.’ So the Chinese ambassador said that they are scrutinising this project very well so that they can complete the work without any mistake as the people of Bangladesh have high expectations for this project. Mentioning that the TMP is a relatively complex project as it includes flood control, river erosion prevention and irrigation activities, she said, ‘Therefore, various issues are being analysed. As a result, China is taking some time to prove its feasibility.’ ‘In addition, China has come forward to build a big hospital,’ she added. The adviser said that political parties have pledged to implement this project. Therefore, disappointment cannot be spread, she said, adding, ‘If an agreement is reached after a study, the money we pay is very difficult to change if more money is needed later.’ Rizwana also emphasised, ‘Achieving a fair share of Teesta river water is an ongoing process. Besides, it is a big political issue.’ So we think that the elected government will come and work to achieve a fair share of water. We have made preparations in the case of the Ganges and the Teesta so that they do not have to wait for the elected government to come, she said. Chinese ambassador Yao Wen said that China had taken a principled decision to implement the Teesta project. ‘It is a big project and it is being scientifically tested.’ Hoping that the elected government will continue to work on the project and maintain its continuity, he also expressed hope for all kinds of cooperation with Bangladesh. Deputy commissioner Mohammad Enamul Ahsan, director of Riverine People Professor Tuhin Wadud and executive engineer of Water Development Board Rabiul Islam, among others, were present. Earlier in the morning, the adviser with the Chinese ambassador and high officials visited the Teesta Road Bridge and Railway Bridge built on the River Teesta at Kaunia. During the visit, Rabiul Islam highlighted the nature and crisis of the Teesta River, which is surrounded by five districts in northern Bangladesh. title: New Age | Shaheed Asad Day today
body: Shaheed Asad Day will be observed today, commemorating the supreme sacrifice of the student leader Asaduzzaman Asad. On January 20 in 1969, Asaduzzaman Asad, a hero of the mass upsurge movement, was killed by the Pakistani police during a protest against atrocities in East Pakistan near Dhaka Medical College Hospital, sparking further unrest. Death of Asad, a student of Dhaka University, accelerated the movement of 1969 while dictator Ayub Khan was forced to leave the power. In observation of the day, president Mohammad Shahabuddin and chief adviser professor Muhammad Yunus issued separate messages, saying that the sacrifice of martyr Asad would remain a source of inspiration for the democracy-loving people of the country. Bangladesh Nationalist Party secretary general Mirza Fakhrul Islam Alamgir also issued a message marking the sacrifice of Asad which influence all uprisings. Various political parties and organisations had chalked our programmes to observe the day, including placing wreaths in the monument near Dhaka Medical College Hospital in the morning. title: New Age | Many secondary students yet to get all textbooks
body: Many secondary-level students across the country are yet to get all free textbooks for this academic year till Monday. At some places, allegations also surfaced that some primary-level students also did not get all free textbooks. According to the National Curriculum and Textbook Board, about 95.28 per cent of the secondary-level textbooks for the 2026 academic year were distributed till Sunday. Earlier, officials of the chief adviser’s press wing and primary and mass education ministry said that the students of pre-primary to primary level and ethnic minority groups got all textbooks. The press wing on January 1 also said that by January 15 all textbooks would be distributed among the students. The same assurance was given by the board on January 4 in a press release. The government on January 1 started distributing free textbooks for the 2026 academic year among students. This year the board set a target to distribute about 30.02 crore books, including 60.67 lakh for pre-primary, 7.90 crore for Class I-V, 1.85 lakh for ethnic minorities, 6.43 lakh for additional pre-primary (4+), 4.43 crore for Class VI, 4.15 crore for Class VII, 4.02 crore for Class VIII, 5.7 crore for Class IX-X, 3.11 crore for Ibtedayi, and 6,026 for Braille method textbooks. Till Sunday, as per the NCTB, all pre-primary to primary, ibtedayi, and ethnic minority-level books were distributed at the educational institutions. The board statistics show that till Sunday, 97.03 per cent of Class VI, 91.71 per cent of Class VII, 92.21 per cent of Class VIII and 98.7 per cent of Class IX books were distributed at the educational institutions. In the capital Dhaka, some primary-level students alleged that they did not get all free textbooks till Monday. For example, all students of Class IV at the Banasree branch of Ideal School and College did not get Bangla book till Monday. Dhaka district primary education officer Md Nurul Hasan said that they had delivered all books to all primary-level educational institutions registered with the Integrated Primary Education Management Information System under the primary and mass education ministry. They held some books for some schools, which remain out of the system yet, he said, adding that they would deliver all books soon. Bandarban district primary education officer Porinoy Chakma said that only a handful of the primary-level schools were yet to collect their books from the upzila offices. Meanwhile, Dhaka district education officer Md Abdul Mazid said that till now some of the free textbooks of Class VII and VIII were yet to be delivered by the board. Within this month, all books will be distributed, he added. Cox’s Bazar district education officer Md Golam Mostafa said that they were yet to get about 4 per cent of secondary-level books from the board. Although the contract with the printing companies is valid until February 3, the board in a press release on January 4 said that by January 15 all textbooks would be distributed among students. On December 28, 2025, at a programme, the NCTB made all 647 textbooks for Bangla and English versions for the 2026 academic year available online for the first time on its web site: www.nctb.gov.bd before distributing their hardcopies among students. The government has been distributing free textbooks among students since 2010. The board faced heavy criticism earlier in 2025 for delaying the delivery of books to students as late as April, four months after their classes had started. Following the criticism, the board decided to set a target to print about 30.02 crore books by November 2025, but eventually failed to reach the target. title: New Age | Trump says world ‘not secure’ until US has Greenland
body: Donald Trump no longer needs to think ‘purely of peace’ after being snubbed for a Nobel, the US president said in comments published Monday, adding the world will not be safe until Washington controls Greenland. Trump has put the transatlantic alliance to the test with threats to take over Greenland ‘one way or the other’, with European countries closing ranks against Washington’s designs on the vast Danish territory. German and French leaders denounced as ‘blackmail’ weekend threats by Trump to wield new tariffs against countries which oppose his plans for the Arctic island, and said Monday that Europe was preparing trade countermeasures. The European Union said it was holding an emergency summit on Thursday to weigh its response, and that while its priority is to ‘engage not escalate’ it is ready to act if needed. Greenland, for its part, said the tariffs threat does not change its desire to assert its own sovereignty. ‘We will not be pressured,’ Greenlandic prime minister Jens- Frederik Nielsen said in a Facebook post, adding that the autonomous territory ‘is a democratic society with the right to make its own decisions’. But Trump had earlier doubled down, announcing in a message to Norway’s prime minister Jonas Gahr Store that the world ‘is not secure unless we have Complete and Total Control of Greenland’. The message — published Monday and whose authenticity was confirmed to AFP by Store’s office — also saw Trump brush aside peace as a primary goal. ‘I no longer feel an obligation to think purely of Peace,’ he said, citing his failure to win the last year’s Nobel Peace Prize, despite openly coveting it. He said although peace would still be ‘predominant,’ he could ‘now think about what is good and proper for the United States of America.’ Store said the statement had been received in response to a message from him and Finnish president Alexander Stubb, where they had ‘conveyed our opposition’ to Trump’s tariff threats. Store also underlined that the Nobel Peace Prize was not awarded by the Norwegian government. ‘I have clearly explained, including to president Trump what is well known — the prize is awarded by an independent Nobel Committee,’ he said in a written statement. Trump has repeatedly said his country needs vast, mineral-rich Greenland for ‘national security’, despite the United States already having a base on the island and security agreements with fellow NATO ally Denmark. ‘Denmark cannot protect that land from Russia or China,’ Trump said in his message to the Norwegian premier, doubling down on that sentiment in a post to Truth Social on Monday. Denmark’s defence minister Troels Lund Poulsen said Monday steps had already been taken along with NATO allies to ‘increase military presence and training activity in the Arctic and the North Atlantic’. Lund Poulsen added that he and Greenlandic foreign minister Vivian Motzfeldt would be meeting with NATO chief Mark Rutte later on Monday. This weekend, Trump said that from February 1, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and Finland would be subject to a 10-per cent tariff on all goods sent to the United States — a duty which could go higher. Germany’s vice chancellor Lars Klingbeil slammed the move as blackmail, and said Monday that Europe was preparing countermeasures. French finance minister Roland Lescure, speaking at a press conference alongside Kingbeil, agreed. ‘Blackmail between allies of 250 years, blackmail between friends, is obviously unacceptable,’ Lecurse said. Klingbeil said Europe’s response could have three main strands. First, the current tariff deal with the United States would be put on hold, he said. Second, European tariffs on imports from the United States, currently suspended until early February, could come into force. And thirdly the EU should consider using its toolbox of instruments against ‘economic blackmail’, he added. Europe’s stock markets fell as the week’s trading began Monday, with British prime minister Keir Starmer warning that a ‘trade war is in no one’s interest’. Greenland — whose tiny population of 57,000 has voiced disquiet at Trump’s threats — continued to make its preferences clear Monday. Greenland’s dogsled federation said that the new US special envoy to the Arctic island had been disinvited to its annual race. Jeff Landry had been invited to attend the race by a private Greenlandic tour operator, an invite the KNQK federation has previously called ‘totally inappropriate’. title: New Age | EC fails to take clear stance on dual citizenship of candidates, says NCP
body: NATIONAL ELECTIONS The National Citizen Party on Monday accused the Election Commission of failing to take a clear legal stance about candidates with dual citizenship, claiming that the commission’s recent actions appeared influenced by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. Speaking at a briefing after a meeting with chief adviser Muhammad Yunus at the State Guest House Jamuna, NCP convener Nahid Islam said that the EC had not ensured the type of electoral environment necessary for a free and fair vote. He alleged that neither the commission nor the field administration was acting impartially. Nahid said that his party raised concerns during meeting with the chief adviser, warning that they would challenge in court over EC’s decision regarding some candidates with dual citizenship. ‘For the past two days, we have observed that the Election Commission has not taken a clear legal position regarding candidates who have dual citizenship,’ he said. ‘Instead, the EC seems to be trying, through legal loopholes and misinterpretation of the constitution, to allow such candidates to contest elections.’ Such attempts on the EC’s part were influenced by the BNP, Nahid alleged. ‘Pressure from BNP leaders and their student organisations through coordinated campaigns and creating mob in front of the EC have influenced decisions even before formal decision was issued,’ he said. While the interim government and chief adviser Yunus have repeatedly claimed they want to conduct the best election in history and are attempting to gain our trust, the necessary conditions for such an election are not evident on the ground, said the NCP convener. ‘The EC cannot interpret the constitution, only the Supreme Court can. The constitution clearly prohibits dual citizens from contesting elections, and the Supreme Court has clarified what constitutes renunciation of foreign citizenship.’ But the EC issued a new interpretation on Sunday, which it legally could not do, apparently to allow BNP-affiliated dual citizens to participate, he added. Similarly, defaulters on loans should not be allowed to contest before settling their debts but an EC member indicated that despite personal reservations, defaulters are being allowed to run, Nahid further alleged. Regarding show-cause notices issued to NCP leaders, he said ‘We raised concerns with the EC regarding impartiality, but instead of addressing them, the commission issued a show-cause notice against us.’ ‘While BNP leader Tarique Rahman’s posters flooded parts of Dhaka, our lawful electoral campaign materials regarding referendum led to action against us,’ he said. According to a press release issued by the chief adviser’s press wing, during the meeting, NCP leaders shared their observations and various concerns regarding the election.
