title: New Age | ‘Yes’ vote to bring new Bangladesh: Yunus
body: ‘Yes’ vote to free Bangladesh from discrimination, exploitation, oppression, he says Interim government chief adviser Muhammad Yunus on Monday in a message urged the voters to vote for ‘Yes’ in the referendum to implement the National July Charter, stressing that the key to building a new Bangladesh was now in the hands of the people. ‘If you vote for ‘Yes’, the door to building a new Bangladesh will open. Cast your vote for ‘Yes,’ encourage everyone you know to do the same, and bring them to the polling stations. Change the country,’ he said. Yunus made the call in a televised message amid criticisms from different quarters over seeking the ‘Yes’ vote in the referendum by the government advisers and officials. ‘I urge all of you to take part in the upcoming referendum. Vote for ‘Yes’ to build the state according to your expectations,’ said Yunus. He said that the ‘July uprising’ was an extraordinary achievement in the nation’s history, creating an opportunity to establish democracy, justice, and human rights in the life of the nation. Noting that a number of reforms have already been undertaken in the spirit of July uprising, he said that a July Charter had been formulated on the basis of consensus among all political parties of the country to carry out deeper and far-reaching reforms. ‘Your consent is required to implement the July Charter, ‘he said, adding that a referendum was therefore being organised for this purpose. ‘Take part in the referendum and give your consent to the charter,’ he added. Noting that the referendum will be held on the same day as the Jatiya Sangsad election, on February 12, he said, ‘If you vote for ‘Yes’ in the referendum, Bangladesh will be free from discrimination, exploitation, and oppression.’ Yunus said that a ‘Yes’ vote in the referendum would mean that the government and the opposition would work together to form a caretaker government and an Election Commission. A ‘Yes’ vote also means that the government will not be able to amend the constitution at will while the consent of the people will be required for any important changes to the constitution. ‘It also provides that the deputy speaker and the chairpersons of key parliamentary committees will be elected from the opposition party,’ he said. He said that a person would not be able to serve as prime minister for more than 10 years and the judiciary would function independently. ‘The representation of women in the Jatiya Sangsad will increase while an upper house will be formed in parliament to maintain a balance of power.’ Yunus said, ‘A ‘Yes’ vote means that people’s fundamental rights will be better protected, the state language, Bangla, will be constitutionally recognised, along with the languages of other ethnic groups.’ ‘The president will not be able to pardon convicted criminals at will while all power will not be concentrated in the hands of the prime minister,’ he explained. title: New Age | Bangladesh EC unveils fresh roadmap for Feb 12 national election
body: Bangladesh Election Commission has rolled out a fresh action plan (roadmap) to smoothly hold the upcoming national election and referendum scheduled for February 12 next. The commission sent the action plan and implementation progress (of the old action plan) to all the divisional commissioners, deputy commissioners and all the EC officials and asked them to take necessary measures accordingly. According to the action plan, the collection of information related to withdrawal of candidacies on January 20, while formation of the vigilance and observation teams, election monitoring teams and the law and order maintenance cell on January 20, sending the lists of polling stations to BG press to publish the lists on January 22 and giving the order to the BG press to print the ballot papers on January 25. The presiding officers, assistant presiding officers, polling officers and the master trainers of polling agents will be trained on January 21 and 22. On the voting day, the EC will collect reporters on the balloting situation and primary results and publish the primary result of elections on the website as per the action plan. Two days after the balloting, the commission will send the names and addresses of elected persons to BG Press for publishing theses in gazettes. The gazettes will be collected from the BG press and the final election results will be published on the website three days after the voting day. On August 28 last year, the Election Commission unveiled the electoral action plan setting timelines to complete all necessary measures to arrange the 13th parliamentary election before Ramadan in February 2026. In the action plan, timeframes were set for different election preparatory works like preparation of the electoral rolls, registration of new political parties, delimitation of parliamentary constituencies, updating the guidelines for observers and journalists, printing of election manual, directives, poster and identity cards, carrying out training activities, making translucent ballot boxes and election materials ready, preparation of election budget, installation of polling stations, law and order related issues, and announcement of election results. title: New Age | Woman, her minor daughter killed in Munshiganj
body: A 32-year-old woman and her minor daughter were stabbed to death at Dakkhin Rajanagar in Sirajdikhan upazila of Munshiganj district on Monday. The deceased were identified as Amena Begum, wife of Mizan Mia and their eight-year-old girl Mariam. Abdul Hannan, officer-in-charge of Sirajdikhan police station, said Amena Begum along with her family used to live at the rented house of one Nuruzzaman Sarkar. Getting no response from the house till noon, local people entered the house and found the bodies of Amena and her daughter. Upon receiving information, police recovered the bodies and sent those to a local hospital morgue. Police said that the husband went into hiding. Preliminary findings suggest that the killings might have been linked to family disputes or an extramarital affair, said the OC. Police are investigating the incidents and trying to arrest Mizan, he said. title: New Age | Bangladesh could be replaced by Scotland: AFP report
body: ICC T20 WORLD CUP Cricket's governing body has told Bangladesh to agree to play their matches at next month's T20 World Cup in India or risk being kicked out of the tournament, reports said Monday. The Bangladesh Cricket Board is refusing to play in India, citing security concerns, and have asked the governing International Cricket Council to shift their matches to co-hosts Sri Lanka. The BCB held talks in Dhaka at the weekend with ICC officials over the impasse, but no agreement was reached. ‘During the discussions, the BCB reiterated its formal request to the ICC to relocate Bangladesh's matches to Sri Lanka,’ a BCB statement said. The ICC have not officially commented, but website Cricinfo and other Indian media reported on Monday that the deadline of Wednesday had been set for Dhaka to make a decision. ICC sources have told AFP that Bangladesh could be replaced by Scotland, who are the highest-ranked team who did not qualify for the World Cup. The T20 World Cup begins on February 7 with Bangladesh in England's Group C and scheduled to play all of their group matches in Kolkata and Mumbai. One suggestion was for Bangladesh to swap with Group B's Ireland, whose matches are in Sri Lanka. ‘Among other points, the possibility of moving Bangladesh to a different group as a means of facilitating the matter with minimum logistical adjustments was discussed,’ said the BCB. Pakistan will play all their matches in Colombo under an ICC agreement with India to play at neutral venues in global or regional tournaments. The row erupted on January 3, when the IPL's Kolkata Knight Riders were ordered by India's cricket board to drop Bangladesh fast bowler Mustafizur Rahman, sparking fury in Dhaka. Political relations between India and Bangladesh soured after a mass uprising in Dhaka in 2024 toppled then-prime minister Sheikh Hasina, a close ally of New Delhi. India's foreign ministry last month condemned what it called ‘unremitting hostility against minorities’ in Muslim-majority Bangladesh. Bangladesh's interim leader, Nobel Peace Prize winner Muhammad Yunus, has accused India of exaggerating the scale of the violence. title: New Age | HC suspends SUST students’ union polls for four weeks
body: The High Court on Monday postponed student union elections at the Shahjalal University of Science and Technology for four weeks. The polls at the university in Sylhet city were supposed to be held today. Later on the day, the university authority filed a petition seeking permission to appeal against the High Court decision. Protesting at the postponement of the polls scheduled for January 20, a section of SUST students later on the day confined the vice-chancellor and pro-vice-chancellor inside the Administrative Building-1, New Age staff correspondent in Sylhet reported. A High Court bench of Justice Fahmida Quader and Justice Md Ashif Hasan passed the order after hearing a writ petition filed by Md Mominur Rashid Shuvo and Md Rakibul Hasan Ratan, both independent candidates vying for the vice-president post in the polls. They challenged the legality of the election commission decision. The court also issued a rule asking the university’s election commission to explain why the decision to allow the polls should not be declared illegal. Senior lawyer Ruhul Quddus Kazal and Rashna Imam appeared for the petitioners. Barrister Rashna told journalists after the HC decision had been passed that the writ petitioners said that holding the SUCSU polls would not be legal on January 20 since Bangladesh Election Commission earlier issued instructions to suspend all types of elections before the National elections scheduled for February 12. ‘The SUCSU elections will not be held tomorrow. But the elections may be held any day after next four weeks,’ she added. Additional attorney general Aneek R Hoque, deputy attorney general Shofiqur Rahman and assistant attorney general Mohiuddin Hanif represented the state, while Mohammad Hossain appeared for the SUST election commission. Immediately after the news of postponing the SUCSU polls had broken, several hundred students, including the supporters of Jamaat-e-Islami-backed student organisation Islami Chhatra Shibir, launched demonstrations at around 2:30pm, blocking Sylhet-Sunamganj road in front of the university’s main entrance at Akhalia in the city in the afternoon. Later at around 5:00pm, they returned to the campus and locked the entrance of the administrative building keeping vice-chancellor Professor AM Sarwaruddin Chowdhury and pro-vice-chancellor Professor Sajedul Karim inside the building, students said. The demonstrations were on with the VC and pro-vice-chancellor still confined as of 10:30pm while this report was filed. Demonstrators at night said that if their demand was not met by 9:00am today they would cut the utility connections of the vice-chancellor’s official residence. University proctor Professor Mokhlesur Rahman told New Age in the evening that they were trying to reach a decision after having a directive from the higher authorities to calm the agitating students. title: New Age | What Sets the Mahindra Bolero Apart from Modern Urban SUVs
body: The SUV market today is largely shaped by urban priorities. Many modern SUVs are designed around city driving, focusing on sleek styling, touchscreen-heavy dashboards, and convenience-led features. While this approach suits metropolitan environments, it does not address the needs of all buyers. The Mahindra Bolero occupies a distinct position by deliberately diverging from the urban SUV formula, offering a vehicle built around strength, simplicity, and long-term reliability. Rather than competing with urban SUVs on refinement or digital sophistication, the Bolero stands out by serving use cases where resilience and practicality take precedence over aesthetics. Most urban SUVs follow a crossover-inspired design language, characterised by sloping rooflines, low ground clearance, and car-like proportions, all aimed at enhancing visual appeal. The Mahindra Bolero takes the opposite approach. Its upright stance, boxy silhouette, and squared-off body panels are functional choices designed to maximise interior space, improve visibility, and withstand physical wear. The latest iteration of the Bolero features a bold new grille, fog lamps, and R15 wheels, with select variants offering diamond-cut alloy wheels and the Stealth Black colour for subtle modernisation without altering its utilitarian identity. This design immediately distinguishes the Bolero from urban SUVs that prioritise styling over substance. One of the most important differences between the Mahindra Bolero and modern urban SUVs lies beneath the surface. While most city-focused SUVs use monocoque construction optimised for comfort and efficiency, the Bolero is built on a high-strength, frame-based body. The Bolero’s robust metal bumper and reinforced structure contribute to its ability to handle prolonged stress and uneven terrain. This ladder-frame architecture is better suited to carrying loads, absorbing impacts, and operating consistently in challenging conditions. Urban SUVs, by contrast, are typically designed for smooth tarmac and lighter usage, making the Bolero structurally distinct. Modern urban SUVs often emphasise refined petrol engines, automatic gearboxes, and fuel efficiency figures aimed at city commuting. The Mahindra Bolero instead relies on a mHawk75 diesel engine, producing 55.9 kW of power and 210 Nm of torque, tuned for low-end strength and consistent pulling ability. This torque-focused tuning supports: The inclusion of Micro Hybrid Technology with Engine Start–Stop improves efficiency during idling, but the overall emphasis remains on reliability rather than smoothness or acceleration. This stands in contrast to urban SUVs, where drivability and refinement are often prioritised over durability. Suspension tuning further separates the Bolero from modern urban SUVs. While city-focused SUVs typically employ comfort-oriented setups designed for smooth roads, the Bolero features an independent front suspension with coil springs and a rigid rear leaf spring arrangement. Bolero’s RideFlo advanced ride and handling technology enhances stability, steering confidence, and braking performance. This configuration is designed to absorb rough surfaces and support heavier loads without compromising structural integrity. Urban SUVs, with their softer suspension setups, are typically not engineered for this level of sustained mechanical stress. Inside, the Mahindra Bolero avoids the design trends commonly seen in modern urban SUVs, such as oversized touchscreens and minimal physical controls. Instead, the cabin focuses on durability and functional comfort. The Bolero’s redesigned seats with improved cushioning, leatherette upholstery in higher variants, and practical storage solutions, including built-in bottle holders and utility spaces in door trims. With seating for seven occupants in a 5+2 configuration, the Bolero supports shared travel and family use. Features such as air conditioning, power windows, central locking, and remote key access provide everyday convenience without relying on fragile or overly complex interfaces. This approach contrasts with urban SUVs, where interior design often prioritises visual appeal over long-term durability. Technology in the Mahindra Bolero is intentionally restrained. Instead of advanced infotainment systems and connected features, the Bolero features essential components that support daily use. The SUV offers a 17.8 cm touchscreen infotainment system, a digital driver information cluster, steering-mounted audio controls, and a USB-C-type charging port. By limiting technological complexity, the Bolero reduces the risk of long-term electronic issues—an important consideration in environments where service access or usage conditions may be demanding. Modern urban SUVs often rely on driver assistance systems to enhance safety. The Mahindra Bolero takes a different route, focusing on robust fundamentals. The Bolero comes with dual airbags, ABS with Electronic Brake-force Distribution, seatbelt reminders, reverse parking sensors, and an engine immobiliser across variants. Combined with the vehicle’s high-strength frame-based construction, these features provide dependable protection in real-world conditions. This safety philosophy prioritises resilience and braking stability rather than electronic intervention. The Bolero’s physical dimensions further reinforce its separation from urban SUVs: These proportions support stability, interior space, and extended driving range—attributes less emphasised in city-centric SUVs. The Mahindra Bolero stands apart from modern urban SUVs because it is built for a fundamentally different purpose. Through frame-based construction, a torque-oriented diesel engine, durable suspension, and function-first interior design, it serves buyers whose priorities extend beyond city comfort and digital features. In an SUV market increasingly shaped by urban lifestyles, the Bolero represents an alternative philosophy—one where strength, simplicity, and long-term dependability remain central. This clear differentiation is what continues to set the Mahindra Bolero apart. title: New Age | JCD stages sit-in blocking EC adjacent roads again
body: Jatiyatabadi Chhatra Dal, the student wing of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, staged a sit-in programme again in front of the Election Commission Bhaban in the Dhaka city on Monday, questioning the commission’s neutrality ahead of the next general election scheduled for February 12. The sit-in programme rolled into the second consecutive days for pressing their three demands — stopping the manipulation of postal ballots for Bangladeshi expatriates living abroad, cancelling what they described as an unprecedented gazette notification issued by the commission to hold Shahjalal University of Science and Technology students’ union polls before the general election under pressure from a student body of a particular political party, and refraining from partisan activities of the commission under pressure from a specific political party. Several thousand leaders and activists blocked roads near EC Bhaban demanding free, fair and credible elections. They started their road block programme at about 11:00am and continued till filing the report at about 4:00pm. On Sunday, they held a sit-in programme from 10:00am to 8:00pm, and withdrew the blockade after getting assurance from the EC to accept their demands. Addressing the sit-in, JCD Jagannath University unit convenor Mehedi Hasan Himel said that the Election Commission failed to ensure neutrality. ‘Some coordinators and some student bodies aligned with fascist Awami League’s student body by hiding their identities, are now trying to foil the election,’ he said. title: New Age | Chinmoy Das, 38 others indicted in Ctg lawyer Alif murder case
body: The Chattogram Divisional Speedy Trial Tribunal on Monday framed charges against 39 people, including former ISKCON organiser Chinmoy Krishna Das Brahmachari, in the case of murdering lawyer Saiful Islam Alif. Judge Md Zahidul Haque of the tribunal passed the order, rejecting discharge petitions filed by 23 detained accused, including Chinmoy, assistant public prosecutor Md Raihanul Wazed Chowdhury said. The court ordered the prosecution to produce their witnesses in phases from February 2 for recording their testimonies, he said. The charge sheet mentioned Chinmoy as an abettor and instigator in the killing of the lawyer. It said that the other accused carried out the killing in a group on Chinmoy’s instruction and provocation. Police produced Chinmoy and 22 others before the court in the morning amid tight security. To avert any untoward situation, more than 100 members of the police, army and Border Guard Bangladesh were deployed on the court premises. On October 25, 2024, Chinmoy led a large gathering of the Hindu community in Chattogram. On October 31, 2024, a sedition case was filed against 19 people, including Chinmoy, on charges of desecrating the national flag. On November 22, 2024, Chinmoy led another large rally in Rangpur, following which he was arrested at Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport in Dhaka on November 25, 2024 in the sedition case. A Chattogram court rejected his bail petition on the following day and sent him to jail. The court’s decision sparked clashes between his followers and the members of the law enforcement agencies on the court premises. At one stage of the clash, lawyer Alif was hacked to death outside the court premises. Several cases were filed against Chinmoy and others following the murder. On April 30, the High Court granted bail to Chinmoy in the sedition case, but the Appellate Division later cancelled the bail. In the murder case, the police on July 1, 2025 filed a charge sheet naming Chinmoy as the prime accused and listing 38 others. During the charge-sheet acceptance hearing, the court rejected the investigation officer’s recommendation to discharge one person, raising the total number of charge-sheeted accused to 39. Of the 39 accused, 16 are still absconding, said the assistant public prosecutor. title: New Age | Bangladeshis granted B1/B2 US visas to face up to $15,000 bond from January 21
body: Starting January 21, 2026, all Bangladeshi nationals approved for a B1/B2 (business and tourist) United States visa will be required to post a bond of up to $15,000. The US Embassy in Dhaka said on Monday that this requirement does not apply to people holding a valid B1/B2 visa issued before January 21, 2026. ‘Do not pay your bond in advance. Paying early does not guarantee you a visa, and third-party sites can be scams,’ said the embassy in a notification through its verified Facebook page. ‘Any payment made before your interview is not refundable. The bond will be returned if you respect the terms of your visa,’ the notification reads. title: New Age | People suffer as battery-run rickshaw pullers block road in city
body: City dwellers had to suffer immensely as battery-run rickshaw pullers blocked the main road in the capital’s Notun Bazar area for two hours on Monday. They staged the demonstration urging the government to allow them to ply their rickshaws on all city roads and withdraw the three-wheelers designed by the Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology. Dhaka Metropolitan Police’s Gulshan Division additional deputy commissioner for traffic, Ziaur Rahman, said that about 500 battery-run rickshaw pullers blocked the road in front of Fuji Tower at about 9:45am and left the place after two hours. ‘We have diverted vehicles and the blockade on one of the busiest roads in the city created congestion in other areas and caused immense suffering to the people,’ he added. Battery-run rickshaw, Van, Easybike Sangram Parishad coordinator Khalikuzzaman Lipon said that they wanted battery-run rickshaw to be allowed to ply on all roads, except highways. He demanded service lanes for rickshaws beside highways. ‘We have no objection to the BUET-designed rickshaws. But if a company makes a monopoly with manufacturing these rickshaws, we will not allow it. We want our local talented manufacturers also make rickshaws following the approved design,’ he said. He said that the design should be approved by the Bangladesh Road Transport Authority through a policy. Following the ouster of the Sheikh Hasina-led Awami League regime on August 5, 2024 amid a student-led mass uprising, the battery-run rickshaws started playing major city roads and highways, defying the government-set rules. The risk of road accidents involving battery-run rickshaws is higher compared to paddle-run rickshaws, revealed a study report published on Sunday. According to the study, 44.45 per cent of the battery-powered rickshaw pullers participating in the study faced serious to very serious accidents, against 29.6 per cent of the participating paddle-run rickshaws. The study, conducted by INNOVISION Consulting in September 2025, also found that the pullers of battery-powered rickshaws were likely to underreport accidents out of fear of regulatory crackdowns. title: New Age | Government orders deposition of licensed firearms by January 31
body: NATIONAL ELECTIONS The government has ordered all firearms licence holders to deposit their weapons at their nearest police stations by January 31 ahead of the 13th Jatiya Sangsad election and referendum, aiming to ensure a free, fair and peaceful election. The directive was issued through a home ministry notification on Sunday. It said that, in line with the announced election schedule, licence holders will be completely prohibited from carrying and displaying firearms until February 15. The restriction, however, will not apply to firearms allocated, under existing policy, for politically important persons and parliamentary candidates and members of law enforcement agencies, the notification said. For candidates, the ban will not apply where a nomination paper has been lawfully submitted to the Election Commission and accepted, or for an armed retainer authorised for the candidate. The ministry warned that violations would face legal action under relevant provisions of the Arms Act, 1878. It also instructed all superintendents of police and other concerned officials to take necessary steps to enforce the order in this regard. Ministry officials said that the submission requirement and temporary restriction on carrying weapons are routine but important measures to maintain law and order during elections and reduce the risk of violence and intimidation. On December 14, the government issued policy guidelines on granting firearms licences and appointing retainers (persons authorised to carry firearms) for politically important individuals and candidates contesting the national election. title: New Age | Beggar killed as LPG-laden truck overturns in Chattogram
body: A pedestrian beggar was killed on the spot when an LPG cylinder-laden truck overturned on the Dhaka–Chattogram highway in Mirsarai upazila of Chattogram on Monday morning. The accident occurred around 7:30am in the Nizampur Government College Bazar area, said Jakir Rabbani, officer-in-charge of Kumira Highway Police Station. The deceased was identified as Abdur Rahman, 42, a resident of South Alinagar under No. 1 Korerhat union in the upazila. Police said he was visually impaired and earned his livelihood by begging. Quoting witnesses, the OC said the Chattogram-bound truck lost control and overturned on the highway around 7:30am. Before overturning, the vehicle hit Abdur Rahman, crushing him against the road divider and killing him instantly. A police team rushed to the spot and conducted rescue operations, he said. The accident caused partial tailbacks on the Chattogram-bound lane. Later, police removed the LPG cylinders and restored traffic movement. The truck driver and his assistant fled the scene, and a regular case is being processed in this connection, the OC added. title: New Age | At least 19 people killed in Chile wildfires, emergency declared
body: Uncontrolled wildfires tore through communities in southern Chile, leaving charred ruins in their wake and at least 19 dead, authorities said, announcing the latest toll on Sunday. More than 50,000 people have been displaced by blazes burning for two days now in the Nuble and Biobio regions about 500 kilometers south of Santiago, fanned by strong winds and hot weather. ‘At 2:30 in the morning, the fire was out of control. There was a whirlwind of fire that consumed the houses in the town below,’ Matias Cid, a 25-year-old student in Penco, told AFP. ‘We had to leave with the shirts on our back. If we had stayed another 20 minutes we would have burned to death,’ he said. Video of the aftermath shows a bleak, empty cityscape of charred homes and burned-out pick-up trucks and cars. Most of the fatalities from the wildfires in the region have so far been in Penco, Mayor Rodrigo Vera said. In neighboring Lirquen, a small port town of about 20,000, the scene was equally devastating, with residents describing how the fire advanced ‘in seconds.’ Many of the residents ‘were saved from the fire because they ran to the beach,’ Alejandro Arredondo, 57, told AFP. ‘Nothing was left standing.’ In the town of Lirquen, soldiers were patrolling the streets as night fell on Sunday. Despite a curfew, some residents armed with flashlights continued working to clear debris or put out fires. President Gabriel Boric declared a state of emergency in Nuble and Biobio as nearly 4,000 firefighters battled the wildfires — raging during the high temperatures of the southern hemisphere summer. The order allows for the deployment of the armed forces to assist. The president traveled to the badly impacted city of Concepcion to oversee the firefighting efforts. Boric announced a nighttime curfew in the most affected towns, warning, ‘conditions are very difficult.’ He returned to Santiago in the evening, pledging to meet with president-elect Jose Antonio Kast on Monday to share information about the forest fires. ‘In difficult times, Chile is united. Our government and the president-elect will work together,’ he said. Alicia Cebrian, the director of the National Service for Disaster Prevention and Response, said most of the evacuations were in the Biobio towns of Penco and Lirquen, which have a combined population of around 60,000 people. The weather forecast Sunday was bad for firefighters — high temperatures and strong winds, said Esteban Krause, the head of a forest preservation agency in Biobio. Wildfires have severely impacted south-central Chile in recent years amid growing signs of the impact of climate change in the South American country, including extreme weather, droughts and floods. In February 2024, several fires broke out simultaneously near the city of Vina del Mar, northwest of Santiago, resulting in 138 deaths, according to the public prosecutor’s office. About 16,000 people were affected by those fires, authorities said. title: New Age | Dhaka’s air continues to be ‘very unhealthy’ with AQI score of 272
body: Dhaka, the densely populated capital of Bangladesh, ranked third among the world’s most polluted cities on Monday morning, recording an Air Quality Index of 272 at about 9:00am. Today, the city’s air was classified as ‘very unhealthy’, indicating a serious health threat, according to the AQI report. Delhi in India, Lahore in Pakistan, and Kolkata in India occupied the first, second, and fourth spots on the list, with AQI scores of 541, 312, and 204 respectively. According to the AQI scale, a reading between 50 and 100 is considered ‘moderate’, with generally acceptable air quality, though sensitive individuals should limit prolonged outdoor exertion. AQI levels of 101–150 are ‘unhealthy for sensitive groups’, 151–200 is ‘unhealthy’, 201–300 is ‘very unhealthy’, and readings above 301 are considered ‘hazardous’, posing severe health risks. The AQI, which reports daily air quality, informs residents how clean or polluted the air is and highlights potential health effects. In Bangladesh, the AQI is calculated based on five key pollutants — particulate matter (PM10 and PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), carbon monoxide (CO), sulfur dioxide (SO2), and ozone. Dhaka has long struggled with air pollution. Air quality usually deteriorates in winter and improves during the monsoon season. The World Health Organisation estimates that air pollution causes about seven million deaths worldwide each year, primarily from stroke, heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, lung cancer, and acute respiratory infections. title: New Age | Body of Jagannath University student recovered from mess in Old Dhaka
body: Police have recovered the hanging body of a student of Jagannath University from Bhatikhana area of Old Dhaka. The body was recovered on Sunday from a mess in the area. Preliminary investigation suggested that it might be a case of suicide. The deceased was identified as Akash Sarkar, a student of the Department of Theatre at Jagannath University. He belonged to the department’s 10th batch. His home district was Faridpur. Ishtiaq, a housemate, said, ‘I was studying for an exam. Later, my brother’s girlfriend called me, after which I started knocking on the room door. At one point the door opened and I saw his body hanging. Then I called the police.’ Nazmul Hasan, an investigation officer of Gandaria Police Station, said, ‘We arrived at the scene at about 9:30pm after receiving the information. The body was recovered in a hanging condition and later sent to Mitford Hospital morgue for post-mortem examinations.’ Editor: Nurul Kabir, Published by the Chairman, Editorial Board ASM Shahidullah Khan on behalf of Media New Age Ltd. +8802-9632245-48 [email protected] For Advertisement, Cell: +8801849 263831 Email: [email protected]

title: New Age | Senegal stun Morocco in chaotic AFCON final
body: FIFA president Gianni Infantino condemned ‘some Senegal players’ for the ‘unacceptable scenes’ which overshadowed their victory in Sunday’s Africa Cup of Nations final when they left the pitch in protest at a penalty awarded to Morocco. African football’s showpiece event was marred by most of the Senegal team walking off when, deep into injury time of normal play and with the match locked at 0-0, Morocco were awarded a spot-kick following a VAR check by referee Jean-Jacques Ndala for a challenge on Brahim Diaz. As a group of their enraged fans fought with Moroccan security personnel at the other end of the stadium, Senegal’s players eventually returned to the pitch to see Diaz shoot a soft penalty into the arms of their goalkeeper Edouard Mendy. Senegal went on to win the final with a brilliant goal from Pape Gueye in extra time, stunning the vast majority of the 66,526 fans at the Prince Moulay Abdellah Stadium in Rabat. ‘We strongly condemn the behaviour of some ‘supporters’ as well as some Senegalese players and technical staff members,’ Infantino said in a statement to AFP. ‘It is unacceptable to leave the field of play in this manner, and equally, violence cannot be tolerated in our sport, it is simply not right.’ African football’s governing body CAF did not allocate blame but said they would take ‘appropriate action’ against those ‘found guilty’. Infantino praised Morocco for its organisation of the tournament -- a boost for the North African nation in what was effectively a dress rehearsal for their co-hosting of the men’s 2030 World Cup. However, Morocco coach Walid Regragui was worried by the damage done globally to African football by the chaotic final. ‘The image we gave of African football was rather shameful. Having to stop the game for more than 10 minutes with the world watching is not very classy,’ said Regragui. Infantino’s statement appeared to be designed to avoid criticising Senegal’s former Liverpool star Sadio Mane, who remained on the pitch and urged his team-mates to return to the game for the penalty. Senegal were already furious at having a goal disallowed for a soft-looking foul minutes earlier. The trouble broke out in the stands as some Senegalese fans tried to enter the field of play and started fighting with security personnel, some smashing chairs over them. The game was held up for almost 20 minutes before Diaz could take the penalty, and his weak ‘panenka’ kick was saved by Mendy. Guey, whose strike in the fourth minute of extra time gave Senegal a 1-0 win, said his team had walked off due to a ‘feeling of injustice’. ‘Just before the penalty we thought we should have had a goal and the referee didn’t go to VAR,’ said Gueye. ‘Sadio told us to come back on and we re-mobilised.’ Senegal coach Pape Thiaw admitted to broadcaster beIN Sports that he had erred in telling the players to walk off. ‘After thinking about it, I realised that I shouldn’t have asked them to go off. I apologise for that,’ said Thiaw. ‘Sometimes you can react in the heat of the moment. Before that we scored a goal that was not given. But now we accept that referees do make mistakes and we apologise.’ Infantino, who was seen talking to Mane during the trophy presentation, said teams have to abide by the match officials’ decisions. ‘We must always respect the decisions taken by the match officials on and off the field of play... because anything less puts the very essence of football at risk.’ Infantino, who will be hoping there are no such scenes in this year’s World Cup finals in the United States, Canada and Mexico, said Sunday’s events sent the wrong message to supporters round the world. ‘It is also the responsibility of teams and players to act responsibly and set the right example for fans in the stadiums and millions watching around the world,’ he said. ‘The ugly scenes witnessed today must be condemned and never repeated... and I expect that the relevant disciplinary bodies at CAF will take the appropriate measures.’ Editor: Nurul Kabir, Published by the Chairman, Editorial Board ASM Shahidullah Khan on behalf of Media New Age Ltd. +8802-9632245-48 [email protected] For Advertisement, Cell: +8801849 263831 Email: [email protected]

title: New Age | China reaffirms support for democratic transition
body: Chinese ambassador to Bangladesh Yao Wen on Sunday met national security adviser Khalilur Rahman and reaffirmed his government’s continued support for Bangladesh’s ongoing democratic transition and conveyed best wishes for the successful conduct of the forthcoming national election. The meeting was held at the chief adviser’s office in Dhaka’s Tejgaon area where both sides exchanged views on issues of mutual interest. They reaffirmed the longstanding friendship and development cooperation between Bangladesh and China. Discussions included the Teesta River Comprehensive Management and Restoration Project and the proposed Bangladesh-China Friendship Hospital. In this context, the Chinese envoy said he would visit the Teesta project area and reiterated China’s commitment to completing the ongoing technical assessment expeditiously, said the Chief Adviser’s press wing. Both sides expressed satisfaction with the positive momentum in bilateral relations and reiterated their shared commitment to further strengthening cooperation for mutual benefit. title: New Age | BGB recovers firearms in Rajshahi, beefs up security
body: Members of Border Guard Bangladesh recovered two US-made pistols along with ammunition during a special search operation at a bordering char area in Rajshahi early Sunday. At a press conference on Sunday afternoon, Rajshahi BGB Battalion commander lieutenant colonel Riaz Shahriar said that acting on a tip-off, three special patrol teams were deployed in the border-adjacent No 10 Char area under Paba upazila at about 11:30pm on Saturday. ‘Using night vision devices, BGB members observed an unidentified person crossing border from the neighbouring country into Bangladesh and burying a bag near a bush before leaving the area,’ he said. As the spot was close to the zero line, the patrol teams refrained from immediate pursuit and waited to see whether local smugglers would retrieve the consignment, he added. After no one appeared until dawn, BGB members searched the area and recovered the buried bag containing two US-made pistols wrapped in cloth, four magazines and eight rounds of ammunition, the commander said. He said that ahead of the upcoming 13th Jatiya Sangsad elections, BGB had intensified border surveillance and security operations across nine upazilas and one city corporation in Rajshahi, covering six parliamentary constituencies. ‘Twenty-eight platoons of mobile and striking forces, two platoons of central reserve forces, K-9 units, seven speedboats and fast patrol craft on the Padma River, and additional striking reserves at 16 border outposts will be deployed. More than 700 BGB members are expected to be engaged in election-related duties,’ he said. He added that 11 temporary base camps would also be set up to ensure effective election security. In three border upazilas, BGB would independently maintain law and order, while in other areas it would work jointly with the army, police, Rapid Action Battalion and Ansar members, he said. Deployment across all election areas is scheduled to be completed between January 29 and February 1, he added. Following deployment, temporary check posts will be established at 30 key points across the nine upazilas and the city corporation, alongside regular patrols to ensure overall security at polling centres. title: New Age | Amir Hamza’s old video sparks political tension in Kushtia
body: AN old video of Mufti Amir Hamza, the Jamaat-e-Islami-nominated candidate for Kushtia-3 (Sadar) constituency and a prominent Islamic preacher, has gone viral on social media, triggering political tension in the area. The 24-second clip shows Hamza distorting the names of the late president Ziaur Rahman and Arafat Rahman Koko, the younger son of former prime minister Khaleda Zia, comparing Koko’s name to that of an animal. The video has drawn strong criticism from local political leaders, activists, and social media users. Kushtia district BNP convener Kutub Uddin Ahmed issued a written protest, describing the language as ‘obscene and irresponsible’ and warning that it could disrupt the election environment ahead of the upcoming parliamentary polls. Engineer Zakir Hossain Sarkar, the BNP-nominated candidate for Kushtia-3, said the party has filed a formal protest and alerted the Election Commission and other relevant authorities regarding the matter. Abdul Hakim Masud, president of the Kushtia District Swechchhasebak Dal, condemned the remarks and demanded a public apology from Hamza. Responding to the controversy, Mufti Amir Hamza on Sunday released a statement on Facebook, claiming the footage was from 2023 and that he had already expressed regret at that time. He accused those circulating the edited video of political manipulation and reiterated his apology, saying ‘I once again express regret for the unintended remarks regarding the late Arafat Rahman Koko.’ Despite his statement, the video continues to generate negative reactions on social media. title: New Age | Osmani medical interns to resume work today
body: The intern doctors of Sylhet Osmani Medical College Hospital on Sunday agreed to resume their duty from today (Monday), after their two days’ work abstention protesting at the attack on their fellow by a patient’s relatives. Mahmudul Hasan Sadiq, a representative of the intern doctors, announced the decision in the afternoon after a meeting with the hospital administration. ‘We will return to our work from 8:00am Monday,’ he said journalists after coming out of the meeting. He said the meeting held with the administration on Saturday was not fruitful. ‘We sat in another meeting today and we decided to return to work after the hospital administration assured us of addressing our demands including ensuring safety of the doctors and staff,’ Mahmudul said. Earlier in the midnight past Friday, the intern doctors of the SOMCH began an indefinite boycott of work protesting at the attack on one of their fellows and the vandalising of a hospital ward allegedly by a patient’s relatives. Witnesses said that relatives of a patient, admitted in Ward 4 on the third floor of the hospital, locked in an altercation with an on-duty intern doctor and staff at around 11:30pm on Friday, alleging that their patient was given wrong treatment. At one stage, they physically assaulted the intern doctor and also attacked the attending staff of the ward, witnesses said, adding that a group of students of Sylhet Osmani Medical College rushed to the spot on information and beat the attackers. Protesting at the incident, the intern physicians announced an indefinite work abstention demanding safe work environment at the hospital and punishment for the attackers. SOMCH director Brigadier General Umar Rashed Munir told New Age in the afternoon that all issues including the demands of the intern doctors have been discussed in the meeting. ‘The intern doctors in the meeting agreed to return to work from Monday morning,’ he added. Meanwhile, the hospital administration recorded a general diary with the Kotwali police station in this incident and a 5-member committee also was formed to investigate the incident properly. title: New Age | 3 electrocuted in Gopalganj
body: Three people were electrocuted at Tentulia village under Rajpat union in Kashiani upazila of Gopalganj Saturday night. The deceased are Rahela Begum, 50, wife of Mosharef Sikder of Tentulia village, her grandson Saifan Sikder, 8, son of Sajib Sikder and Iran Sikder, 55, son of their neighbour Hanif Sikder. The incident occurred at around 8:30 pm. Officer-in-charge of Kashiani police station Mohammad Mahfuzur Rahman said an electric wire had been laid as a trap near the house of Sajib Sikder to protect Boro rice seedlings from rats. He said Saifan first came into contact with the live wire at around 8:30pm and was electrocuted. Hearing his screams, his grandmother Rahela Begum rushed to rescue him but was also electrocuted and died on the spot. Neighbour Iran Sikder later attempted to save them and was likewise electrocuted, the OC added. title: New Age | Politicians show last respect to Hazera Sultana
body: Politicians and people from all walks of life paid their last respects to Workers Party of Bangladesh Politburo member Hazera Sultana by placing wreaths on her body. The body of Hazera Sultana was brought to the Workers Party central office on Topkhana Road at 10 am on Sunday, where it remained for one hour for people to pay their last respects. Party politburo member, freedom fighter and former member of parliament Hazera Sultana, died in a private city hospital on Thursday night, suffering from old age complications at the age of 75. Acting president of the Workers Party Mahmudur Hasan Maink, acting general secretary Nur Ahmed Bakul and central leaders of the party, a central delegation of Jatiya Samajtantrik Dal-Jasod led by standing committee member Shafi Uddin Molla and central leaders of various front organisations of Workers Party also placed wreaths on the body. The body was brought to her parental home at Kalihati upazila in Tangail, and buried in the family graveyard in the afternoon following namaz-e-janaza, where Kalihati thana police gave a guard of honour as she was a freedom fighter. A central delegation of the party led by Nur Ahmed Bakul, along with the deceased’s sole daughter Rana Sultana and others, went to Kalihati, a party press release said. title: New Age | Battery-powered rickshaws pose higher accident risk: study
body: The risk of road accidents involving battery-powered rickshaws is higher compared to paddle-run rickshaws, revealed a study report on Sunday. As per the findings of the study, 44.45 per cent of the battery-powered rickshaw pullers participating in the study faced serious to very serious accidents against 29.6 per cent of the participating paddle-run rickshaws. The study, conducted by INNOVISION Consulting in September 2025, also found that pullers of battery-powered rickshaws were likely to underreport accidents over fear of regulatory crackdowns. At the report launch event, urban planners, experts and stakeholders urged the government to allow the transition of the paddle-run rickshaws to battery-run by checking all safety sides and expenses. The report titled ‘Urban mobility study in Dhaka: rickshaws in transition’ was launched at an event at BDBL Building in the capital on Sunday. The study explores the economic, social and operational dimensions of rickshaws in Dhaka, focusing on drivers, passengers and garage owners. The study is based on primary data collected from 384 rickshaw pullers, 392 passengers and 63 garage owners across Dhaka city. While presenting the key findings of the study, INNOVISION Consulting managing director Md Rubaiyath Sarwar said that the study examined the rapid transition of Dhaka city’s transport-scape as paddle-driven rickshaws were transformed to battery-powered vehicles. As per the findings, 82 per cent sample passengers prefer battery-powered rickshaws for faster commute and primarily use the vehicle for short-distance travel covering 1–3 kilometres. In the study, 30 per cent respondent passengers reported accidents involving battery-powered rickshaws, compared with 18 per cent accidents involving paddle-run rickshaws, with injuries from battery-powered rickshaw accidents reported as more serious. Regarding Dhaka city corporation registration, 97.4 per cent of the battery-powered rickshaws and 85.94 per cent of the paddle-run rickshaws were operating without any registration. Battery-powered rickshaws which were found to have city corporation registration actually got their registration when they were paddle-run rickshaws. Urban and regional planning professor Akter Mahmud of Jahangirnagar University said that while addressing the rickshaw issue the authorities must consider increasing public transport and pedestrian facilities. Dhaka Transport Coordination Authority’s traffic enforcement officer Md Selim Khan said that currently 8–10 lakh paddle-run and 10 lakh battery-powered rickshaws ply in Dhaka city. The findings also reveal that 75 per cent of the battery-powered rickshaw pullers are new entrants who never drove paddle-run rickshaws. Battery-powered rickshaw pullers earn higher gross daily income (Tk 880 on average) than paddle-run rickshaw pullers (Tk 594 on average), but due to high rental costs, battery-powered rickshaw pullers earn lower net income. Self-owned battery-run rickshaw pullers, however, earn significantly higher. For transition, 42.34 per cent of the battery-powered rickshaw pullers mentioned less physical stress followed by 31.53 per cent mentioned higher demand from passengers and 20.72 per cent mentioned higher income. For owning rickshaws, 59.7 per cent battery-powered rickshaw pullers took microfinance while 60 per cent paddle-run rickshaw pullers used personal savings. Of the sample garage owners, 62 per cent preferred battery-powered rickshaws for higher demand and income potential, while they also expressed concerns about frequent repairs and maintenance costs. The discussants at the report launch programme also stressed using more environmental-friendly battery for motorised rickshaws. Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology professor Md Musleh Uddin Hasan, Voice for Reform co-conveners Fahim Mashroor and Syed Hasibuddin Hossain, Akij Motors general manager Iftekhar Hossain, Padakkhep Manabik Unnayan Kendra joint director Shazib Hasnat, European Union programme manager Taif Hossain, Cassetex Ltd cofounder Tauseef Anwar and Shebok vice-president Md Monirul Islam spoke at the event, among others. The two Dhaka city corporations on January 3 this year inaugurated relatively environment-friendly ‘e-rickshaws’ manufactured by BUET experts on pilot basis in three areas in the city. title: New Age | Iran considers ‘gradually’ restoring internet after shutdown
body: Iranian authorities have said they are considering ‘gradually’ restoring internet access after imposing an unprecedented communications shutdown 10 days ago, which rights groups say masked a violent protest crackdown that killed thousands. Demonstrations sparked in late December by anger over economic hardship exploded into protests widely seen as the biggest challenge to the Iranian leadership in years. Iranian officials have said the demonstrations were peaceful before turning into ‘riots’ and blamed foreign influence, namely from Iran’s foes the United States and Israel. The rallies subsided after the crackdown that rights groups have called a ‘massacre’ carried out by security forces under the cover of a communications blackout that started on January 8 as the protests grew in size and intensity. Government officials have said calm has been restored, with schools reopening on Sunday — Iran’s weekend falling on Thursday and Friday — after a week of closure. Late Saturday, the Tasnim news agency reported ‘the relevant authorities announced that internet access would also be gradually restored’, but gave no further details. Citing an unnamed ‘informed source’, the agency said local messaging applications ‘will soon be activated’ on Iran’s domestic intranet. On Sunday morning, AFP was able to connect to the internet from its Tehran office, though the vast majority of internet providers and mobile internet remain cut. Outgoing international calls have been possible since Tuesday, and text messaging was restored Saturday morning. For days, text messages and international phone calls — and at times even local calls — were cut off. Iran has since been relying on its intranet, which has supported local media websites, ride-hailing apps, delivery service and banking platforms. Despite the restrictions, information had still filtered out, with reports of atrocities emerging, according to rights groups. Amnesty International said it had verified dozens of videos and accounts in recent days. They showed ‘that security forces have been relentlessly firing at protesters from the streets and from elevated positions’ and that hospitals had been ‘overwhelmed with the injured’ in a ‘massacre of protesters’, said Amnesty’s Iran researcher Raha Bahreini in a video posted online. Norway-based rights group Iran Human Rights says it has verified the deaths of 3,428 protesters killed by security forces, confirming cases through sources within the Islamic republic’s health and medical system, eyewitnesses and multiple independent sources. However, the NGO warns the true toll is likely far higher. Media cannot independently confirm the figure and Iranian officials have not given an exact death toll for the protests. Other estimates place the death toll at more than 5,000 — and possibly as high as 20,000 — though the internet blackout has severely hampered independent verification, IHR says. The opposition Iran International channel based outside the country has said at least 12,000 people were killed during the protests, citing senior government and security sources. Iran’s judiciary has rejected that figure. On Saturday, supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said ‘a few thousand’ people had been killed by what he called ‘agents’ of the United States and Israel, and Iranian local media has reported multiple deaths among security forces. Khamenei said authorities ‘must break the back of the seditionists’, as local media has reported thousands of arrests and rights groups have estimated up to 20,000 people have been detained. On Sunday, Iran’s judiciary spokesman Asghar Jahangir reiterated that swift trials would be held, warning that some acts were tantamount to the capital offence of ‘moharebeh’, or ‘waging war against God’. ‘All those who played a decisive role in these calls for violence, which led to bloodshed and significant damage to public finances, will not be spared,’ he said. Alarm has grown over the threat of capital punishment against arrested protesters, even as Donald Trump said Iran had called off hundreds of executions. The US president, who backed and joined Israel’s 12-day war against Iran in June, had repeatedly threatened new military action against Tehran if protesters were killed. Analyst Arif Keskin cast doubt on Trump’s claim, saying ‘the Iranian leadership sees executions as an effective tool to end protests, prevent them, and suppress them’. ‘For the regime, executions will carry short-term international costs but are seen as a long-term investment in domestic security,’ the Ankara-based Iranian researcher and Middle East specialist said. ‘The risk therefore remains very real.’ Editor: Nurul Kabir, Published by the Chairman, Editorial Board ASM Shahidullah Khan on behalf of Media New Age Ltd. +8802-9632245-48 [email protected] For Advertisement, Cell: +8801849 263831 Email: [email protected]

title: New Age | Netanyahu holds coalition meeting after objecting to Gaza panel
body: Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu convened a meeting of his ruling coalition partners on Sunday after objecting to the composition of a Gaza advisory panel formed by the White House, according to an official and media reports. The White House announced this week the setting up of a ‘Gaza Executive Board,’ which would operate under a broader ‘Board of Peace’ to be chaired by US president Donald Trump as part of his 20-point plan to end the war in Gaza. The executive board, described as having an advisory role, includes Turkish foreign minister Hakan Fidan and Qatari diplomat Ali Al-Thawadi, alongside other regional and international officials. Late on Saturday, Netanyahu’s office objected to the composition of the executive board. ‘The announcement regarding the composition of the Gaza Executive Board, which is subordinate to the Board of Peace, was not coordinated with Israel and runs contrary to its policy,’ the office of Netanyahu said. ‘The prime minister has instructed the foreign affairs minister to contact the US secretary of state on this matter.’ It did not explain the reason for its objection, but Israel has previously objected strongly to any Turkish role in post-war Gaza, with relations between the two countries deteriorating sharply since the war began in October 2023. In addition to naming Turkey’s foreign minister to the executive board, Trump has also invited Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan to join the overarching Board of Peace. Media reports said that leaders of the country’s ruling coalition were scheduled to meet on Sunday to examine the composition of the executive board. ‘There is a meeting scheduled of the coalition at 10:00am (0800 GMT),’ the spokesman of Netanyahu’s Likud Party said. Alongside Likud, the coalition includes the Religious Zionist Party led by far-right finance minister Bezalel Smotrich and Otzma Yehudit Jewish Power led by far-right national security minister Itamar Ben Gvir. The White House said Trump’s plan would include three bodies: the Board of Peace, chaired by Trump; a Palestinian committee of technocrats tasked with governing Gaza; and the Gaza Executive Board, which would play an advisory role. The Palestinian technocratic committee held its first meeting in Cairo on Saturday. The diplomatic developments came as the United States said this week that the Gaza truce plan had entered a second phase, shifting from implementing a ceasefire to the disarmament of Hamas, whose October 7, 2023 attack on Israel triggered the Israeli offensive in Gaza. title: New Age | Man beaten to death, attackers yet to be identified
body: Attackers who lynched a man at Kabirhat upazila in Noakhali on Saturday night had yet to be identified by the police till Sunday evening. Deceased Mizanur Rahman Rony, 35, a resident of Jaindapur area of Kabirhat municipality, was the father of two children, the police said, adding that he was implicated in multiple criminal cases, including arms and robbery cases. Rony was attacked at about 10:00pm Saturday on the road in front of Kazi Bari adjacent to Kalirhat Bazar in Ward 2 of Narottampur union, said Md Nizam Uddin Bhuiyan, Kabirhat police officer-in-charge. ‘On information that a man was beaten to death, the police went to the scene. A toy pistol and a switchblade were recovered from his pocket,’ he said. Perpetrators were yet to be identified while the family asked for some time to file a formal complaint, OC Nizam said, adding that legal action would be taken following an investigation once a complaint was received. Sometime before he was attacked, Mizanur had a heated argument with local Bangladesh Nationalist Party activists who were having an election-related meeting at their office at Kalirhat Bazar at about 8:00pm. ‘We were in a meeting at our office when Mijanur entered and became engaged in an argument, former BNP president for Ward 2 Harunur Rashid Harun said. Saying that Mizanur left the office at one point, Harun stated, ‘later I heard that unidentified people killed him and left his body on the road.’ Mijanur reportedly claimed himself as a ‘dedicated worker’ of the BNP, said several individuals who claimed they had witnessed the heated argument. They also said that he was chased out by the BNP activists present at the office. Later, several of them reportedly caught him in front of Kazi Bari and beat him indiscriminately, leaving him dead on the spot, witnesses claimed. Meanwhile, some youths reportedly distributed sweets at a nearby market following the incident, allegedly branding the deceased a ‘robber’. title: New Age | Seven-year old strangled to death
body: A man allegedly strangled his daughter to death at Char Basanti Purba Para village of Nakla Upazila in Sherpur on Sunday. The deceased is Morium, 7, daughter of Babu Mia. His another daughter Mim Akter, aged three and a half years, was admitted to Sherpur District Hospital with injuries on neck. Nakla police station officer-in-charge Ripon Chandra Gop said being informed by locals Morium’s body was recovered from the spot. Police arrested Babu Mia when he was trying to flee, he said. Initial investigations indicate that Babu locked into an altercation with his wife Hasina Begum over family feud and at one stage he strangled Morium to death, said OC-investigation Abul Kashem. The father also attacked younger daughter Mim, leaving her injured. Local people demanded strict punishment for the killer. title: New Age | 2 burnt bodies recovered at Savar
body: Police recovered two charred bodies from an abandoned community centre in Savar municipality area on Sunday. Local people spotted the bodies at the community centre, about 500 yards away from Savar model police station premises and informed police through national emergency number 999 who recovered the bodies in the afternoon, said Arman Ali, officer-in-charge of the police station. ‘As the bodies are burnt their identities could not be ascertained immediately. We are investigating,’ said the OC. With the latest recovery, five bodies have been found at the abandoned community centre over the past six months. On August 29, last year, police recovered the body of an unidentified young man with his hands and legs tied from the same location and on October 11, the body of an unidentified woman, aged around 30, was found there. On December 19, police recovered the body of a man from a second-floor toilet of the same community centre. Expressing concern over the repeated recovery of bodies, local people said various criminal activities occur at the abandoned community centre but no effective action has been taken yet. title: New Age | Russian drone strike kills woman in Kharkiv
body: A Russian strike on Ukraine’s northeastern city of Kharkiv killed a 20‑year‑old woman and wounded several others overnight, regional officials said early Sunday. ‘There is information about one person killed as a result of an enemy drone strike on a private house,’ Kharkiv mayor Igor Terekhov said on Telegram. Regional governor Oleg Synegubov later said a UAV slammed into the residence, killing a 20‑year‑old woman and wounding another. Synegubov also said a 41‑year‑old woman suffered an ‘acute stress reaction’ after the strike. The strikes extended beyond Kharkiv. In the northeastern Sumy region, emergency services said an air strike on a residential neighbourhood wounded three women and a seven‑year‑old child. Preliminary assessments showed damage to 15 residential buildings. In the Odesa region, Izmail district officials reported another Russian attack, again targeting critical infrastructure sites. Initial information indicated no casualties, though officials said the strike continued a pattern of repeated assaults on the Danube port region. The strikes come as Ukrainian negotiators arrived in the United States Saturday for talks with president Donald Trump’s administration on how to end four years of war with Russia, expected to focus on security guarantees and post-war recovery. The war is Europe’s worst conflict since World War II. More than 200,000 homes in Russian-occupied southern Ukraine were left without power following a Ukrainian army attack, the Moscow-installed authorities said Sunday. ‘Following an enemy attack on the region’s energy infrastructure, a large part of the Zaporizhzhia region has been left without electricity,’ Moscow-installed official Yevgeny Balitsky said on Telegram. According to Balitsky, the attack cut power to 2,13,000 customers and 386 localities in the Zaporizhzhia region. Vladimir Saldo, the Moscow-installed governor of the neighbouring Kherson region, said on Saturday evening that a Ukrainian strike had hit an electrical substation, causing outages in 14 towns and 450 villages. He later said that emergency repair work had restored power. Russia has hit Ukraine with daily drone and missile barrages in recent months, targeting energy infrastructure and cutting power and heating in the frigid depths of winter. Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky last week declared a ‘state of emergency’ for the sector and said work was under way to increase the country’s electricity imports. ‘The situation in the energy system remains difficult, but we are doing everything we can to restore all services as quickly as possible,’ he said Sunday. According to Ukraine’s air force, Russia launched 201 drones overnight from Saturday to Sunday, 167 of which were shot down. Two people were killed, Zelensky said. title: New Age | COBA offers free cataract surgery
body: US-based donor organisation Charity Organisation of Bangladeshi Arizonas (COBA) held a free eye treatment and cataract surgery programme at Padma Government College premises on Saturday with the slogan ‘Everyone will see the light’. About three hundred patients were examined and 61 patients were finally selected for cataract surgery under the supervision of ‘Poverty Eradication Organisation’. The patients will later undergo cataract surgery and lens implantation at Bangladesh Eye Hospital in Dhaka with free transport facilities. The objective of this programme was to restore their eyesight and improve the quality of life by providing advanced eye treatment free to the economically backward people of Dohar and Srinagar upazilas. Since its inception, the Charity Organisation of Bangladeshi Arizonas (COBA) has been providing scholarships to the poor and talented students, free treatment to the helpless poor, creating women entrepreneurs, increasing social awareness and implementing various programs for sustainable development. To make the daylong programme a success, the Poverty Eradication Organisation chairman and former health advisor Major General (retd) Professor AR Khan, one of the patrons and its vice-chairman Major General (Retd) Professor KM Omar Hasan, treasurer Abul Bashir Khan, eminent social worker Abdur Rahman Pakhi, and Akhtaruzzaman Nipu were present. Mohammad Ali Sagar, eminent businessman and social worker, Poverty Eradication secretary general Obaidur Rahman Khan, executive member Associate Professor Mohammad Ilias Hossain, Rotarian Yunus Ali Dipu, members of the management committee and local dignitaries attended the event. title: New Age | RUCSU GS removes congratulatory banner for Tarique Rahman
body: Rajshahi University Central Students’ Union general secretary Salahuddin Ammar on Sunday removed a congratulatory banner put up on the campus welcoming Tarique Rahman on becoming the Bangladesh Nationalist Party’s chairman. At about 2:30pm, Ammar removed the banner installed on Paris Road by professor Mohammad Nesar Uddin, the RU Arabic department professor and Zia Parishad Rajshahi district unit president. Earlier in the day at about 11:30am, Ammar issued an ultimatum through a Facebook post, asking the relevant teacher to remove the banner by 2:00pm. In the post, he cited Section 55 (2) of the Rajshahi University Act, 1973, claiming that it prohibits party politics, political campaign on campus, and the use of teachers’ associations for partisan political activities. However, Section 55 (2) of the act states that ‘the service conditions shall be determined without any prejudice to the freedom of the teacher or officer to hold any political views and to keep association with any lawful organisation outside the University and shall be clearly stated in the contract.’ After removing the banner, Ammar shared a video on Facebook explaining that he had requested the teacher remove it within the stipulated time and since no action was taken, he removed it himself as a student. ‘I will oppose any display of partisan banner politics by teachers whenever I see it on campus. Teacher politics is destroying education and turning individuals into political brokers,’ he wrote. In another Facebook post, Ammar said that the same stance would be applied to Jamaat-e-Islami as well, though he claimed that the party had so far not displayed any banners, held rallies or openly expressed political identity on the campus. ‘You may belong to or practise the politics of any party, but do it outside the campus,’ he added. Ammar further said that while students were demanding a ban on student politics, the root of the problem lay in what he described as ‘dangerous teacher politics’, urging students to become vocal against it. Contacted, Ammar told New Age that the explicit mention of the phrase ‘outside of the university’ in Section 55 clearly implied that no political activities were permitted within the university premises. He argued that if political activities were lawful inside the campus, there would have been no need to specifically mention ‘outside’ in the ordinance. He further claimed that legal language was not always written in a literal or plain manner; rather, it required contextual and interpretative understanding. Meanwhile, terming the incident ‘barbaric’, professor Mohammad Nesar Uddin questioned how a congratulatory banner in Tarique Rahman’s honour could cause any harm to Rajshahi University. ‘I strongly condemn and protest this act,’ he said, alleging that student leaders were neglecting their studies and instead roaming the campus monitoring activities. ‘I leave the judgement of this matter to the nation,’ he added. title: New Age | CMP drops two names from ‘miscreants’ list’ after criticism
body: The Chattogram Metropolitan Police on Sunday revised its list of 330 people, whom it termed ‘miscreants’, dropping two names amid criticism over the publication. The dropped names include Bangladesh Nationalist Party’s Chattogram city joint convener Shawkat Azam Khaza and late former ward councilor Ataullah Chowdhury, said the metropolitan police’s assistant commissioner (public relations and media) Aminur Rashid. The names were dropped a day after the metropolitan police on Saturday published the list and banned the people’s entry and stay in Chattogram. AC Aminur said that the inclusion of the two names was an ‘unintentional mistake’ and the list was corrected after re-verification. With the revision on Sunday, the number of people on the list now stands at 328, he said. After publishing the list, different quarters criticised it. BNP’s Chattogram city unit, in a press release on Sunday, condemned the inclusion of its leaders and activists in the CMP list and alleged a lack of transparency in preparing the list. It claimed that the initial list had included names of 15 BNP leaders and activists, including Shawkat Azam. They also alleged that the list included names of dead people and that some people who faced ‘false’ cases over the past 17 years for joining movements demanding a neutral election. The list includes names of police-listed top crime suspects, muggers, leaders of the Awami League, Bangladesh Chhatra League and absconding former Awami League lawmakers. The names include former education minister Mohibul Hasan Chowdhury Nowfel and former Awami League lawmakers Fazle Karim Chowdhury, MA Latif and Mohiuddin Bachchu, and top crimes suspect Sajjad Ali Khan alias Boro Sajjad and Sajjad Hossain alias Chhoto Sajjad. title: New Age | Fakhrul’s ‘Memories and Miseries’ selected in Nepal film fest
body: Mohammad Fakhrul Alam-written and directed short film titled Memories and Miseries has been selected in the Nepal International Film Festival 2026. The film has been selected for the International Shorts Competition, fiction, category scheduled to be held in Kathmandu from April 2 to 6. Memories and Miseries revolves around a soul revisiting three fragments of its existence— a solitary writer, a war-haunted priest and his soul being in the state of limbo— searching for meaning through spirituality, loneliness and the memories full of sufferings. The film follows the introspective journey of a soul who is caught between divinity and the complications of human emotion. Lying by the riverside, the soul revisits scattered periods of its life: one as a writer exploring the human condition and another as a priest scarred by war. The film explores the interwoven threads of memory, fate and the eternal struggles between transcendence and suffering. Each life, a moment in the soul’s quest for meaning, leaves behind traces of joy, pain and redemption. Fakhrul Alam has said that in creating and developing Memories and Miseries, he has attempted to explore the deeper, unspoken layers of human lives— the moments where memory and emotion collide, where the soul grapples with its purpose and its past. ‘Traveling for almost a decade throughout the country like a dervish, I had always longed for expressing stories I have lived through,’ he mentioned. Harif Siraj, Khalid Hasan Rumi and Fakhrul Alam have played different roles in the film while Ariq Anam Khan leads the narration from background. title: New Age | Meghdoot Natya Sampraday premieres Shaista Kha’r Pori
body: Theatre troupe Meghdoot Natya Sampraday premiered their 21st production titled Shaista Kha’r Pori at the experimental theatre hall of Bangladesh Shilpakala Academy on Sunday. The play Shaista Kha’r Pori, directed by Subhasish Datta Tanmoy, was written by Abu Sayed Tulu based on Ismail Hossain’s historical novel of the same title. The play narrated the tragic death of Pori Bibi, daughter of Mughal Subahdar of Bengal, Shaista Kha, and also detailed the historical architecture of Lalbagh Fort in the old city of Dhaka. Pori Bibi’s marriage was scheduled with Prince Muhammad Azam Shah, the son of Emperor Aurangzeb. Shaista Kha supervised the construction of the fort, but the sudden death of Pori Bibi stopped the project. The play also portrays the history of Bengal and Shaista Kha’s tenure as a ruler. The play’s stage was designed by Fazle Rabbee Sukarno, with lighting by Henry Sen and costumes by Irene Parveen Lopa. Hamidur Rahman Pappu composed the music and Subhasish Datta Tanmoy was responsible for the makeup design. title: New Age | Bangladesh earn first win in SAFF Futsal
body: Bangladesh men’s team secured their first win in the SAFF Futsal Championship as they beat Bhutan 4-1 in their third match of the seven-nation tournament at the Nonthaburi Stadium in Bangkok, Thailand, on Sunday. Moin Ahmed scored a brace, while Foysal Hossain and Kazi Ibrahim Ahamed each scored once for Bangladesh, with Bhutan captain Kinga Wangchuk scoring one goal. Bangladesh captain Rahbar Wahed Khan, though not on the scorers’ list, played a vital role in the match by assisting three goals. Bangladesh took the lead in the fifth minute when Moin’s shot found the net following a cross from Rahbar. Moin doubled the score in the tenth minute as Bangladesh dominated first-half 2-0. Bhutan responded in the 29th minute when Wangchuk scored from a narrow angle on the left. Foysal extended the lead 3-1 in the 35th minute with a tap-in following a pass from Rahbar, and Ibrahim made it 4-1 in the 36th minute after quick service from Rahbar. Bangladesh played a 4-4 draw against India before suffering a crushing 6-1 defeat to Maldives in the second game. Bangladesh will play Sri Lanka on Tuesday before facing Pakistan and Nepal on January 22 and 24, respectively. title: New Age | 10 DU students receive Professor Sitara Parvin Award
body: Ten students of the Department of Mass Communication and Journalism at Dhaka University on Sunday received ‘Professor Sitara Parvin Award’ for their outstanding results in Bachelor of Social Sciences 2023 examinations. University pro-vice chancellor (administration) Professor Sayema Haque Bidisha as chief guest of the ‘Professor Sitara Parvin Award Ceremony 2026’ handed over the awards to the recipients at the professor Muzaffar Ahmed Chowdhury Auditorium on the campus, said a press release issued by the university’s public relations office. The programme was chaired by department acting chairman and dean of the Faculty of Social Sciences Professor Taiabur Rahman, while The Daily Star editor Mahfuz Anam addressed the event as guest speaker. Associate professor Shaonti Haider presented a brief biography of Professor Sitara Parvin and retired professor Ahaduzzaman Mohammad Ali delivered the vote of thanks at the ceremony conducted by assistant professor Marzia Rahman. Addressing the event, pro-vice chancellor Professor Sayema Haque Bidisha said that the award was recognition of merit and hard work and would encourage them to move further ahead. Paying tributes to late Professor Sitara Parvin, she said that such initiatives would help the new generation learn about her life and contributions. The award recipients are Azra Humayra, Muhammad Muzzammil Haque, Abir Ferdous Ayon, Kouritra Podder Tirtha, Asrifa Sultana Reya, Sumaiya Jahan, Afrina Sultana, Badhan Dev, Afrin Jahan and Md Rafiuzzaman Labib. Expressing her feelings on receiving the award, Azra Humayra told New Age that it was an honour to receive the Sitara Parvin Award. ‘The award would act as a reminder for me to be a good journalist,’ she added.
